advanced-research-methods-(hdfs-7780)/re.title: @daniello20YearReview2020
advanced-research-methods-(hdfs-7780)/re.description:
Bibliography: Type: Journal Article Title: A 20‐Year Review of Common Factors Research in Marriage and Family Therapy: A Mixed Methods Content Analysis, Author: D'Aniello, Carissa; Fife, Stephen T.; Journal: Journal of Marital and Family Therapy, Volume: 46, Issue: 4 Pages: 701-718 Year: 2020 DOI: 10.1111/jmft.12427 ISSN: 0194-472X, 1752-0606 Introduced by Sprenkle, Blow & Dickey (1999), common factors in marriage and family therapy (MFT) have been discussed over the past two decades. Although the MFT common factors literature has grown, there are misconceptions and disagreements about their role in theory, practice, research, and training. This content analysis examined the contributions of the common factors paradigm to MFT theory, practice, research, and training over the past 20 years. We identified 37 scholarly works including peer‐reviewed journal articles, books, and chapters. Using mixed methods content analysis, we analyze and synthesize the contributions of this literature in terms of theoretical development about therapeutic effectiveness in MFT, MFT training, research, and practice. We provide commentary on the substantive contributions that the common factors paradigm has made to these areas, and we discuss the implications and limitations of the common factors literature, and provide recommendations for moving common factors research forward. Keywords: Need to Read Randomized controlled trials (RCTs), long considered the gold standard for testing the effectiveness of treatment approaches and interventions, rest on the assumption that models and interventions are responsible for change. Common Factors are defined as the general mechanisms of change that cut across models, rather than aspects of treatment that are unique to a particular model. Common factors, rather than model-specific factors, are largely responsible for effective therapy. Despite increased theoretical and empirical support for common factors, there has been continued debate about their usefulness in the MFT field. The purpose of this content analysis is to critically analyze, synthesize, and clarify the contributions of the common factors paradigm to MFT theory, research, training, and practice.
Common Factors are an umbrella term for the general mechanisms or variables associated with therapeutic change that are common across therapy models. Common factors, also called general factors or mechanisms of change, are factors that contribute to change in psychotherapy. They are not the province of a specific model but instead are found in all therapies. Common factors are further defined as broad and narrow. Broad common factors include general aspects of treatment such as client and therapist factors, extra-therapeutic variables (e.g., foruitous events, social support), therapist-client relationship factors, and the client's expectancy of the success of therapy. Empirical support for common factors is grounded in outcome studies and meta-analyses of therapeutic effectiveness. Narrow common factors refer to aspects of treatment found in several models that go by different names.
Different models of therapy share common processes or goals, otherwise defined as Model-Dependent Common Factors. These include shifting each partner's cognition, affect, or behavior; reattribution; reinforcement; desensitization; and psychoeducation and skills training. What are some examples of common factors in your own work with the various theories? How often do they overlap? The MFT field has traditionally conceptualized and explained therapeutic effectiveness through the lens of models. Therapy is effective because of the unique and particular philosophy or intervention of each therapeutic model. However, several meta-analyses of psychotherapy demonstrate this is not the care, finding no model of couple and family therapy consistently yielding better results than others. It is important to critically examine the impact, strengths, and limitations of this paradigm as applied to MFT theory and practice. What are the primary characteristics of common factors literature in the MFT field? What common factors are identified in the MFT literature? How do common factors researchers draw distinctions between change mechanisms, change process, and common factors? How do common factors contribute to the discussion about the therapeutic effectiveness of MFT? How do MFT scholars explain the relationship between common factors and models? How do common factors inform and enhance MFT practice, research, and training? How does the MFT common factors literature answer fundamental questions about therapeutic effectiveness and the process of change in therapy? We used the following criteria to determine whether to include works in our sample: Common factors are the primary focus of the work The authors discuss common factors as applied to the practice of MFT The work was published in a peer-reviewed journal or academic outlet between 1999 and early 2019. The authors have written about common factors extensively. Throughout the data analysis and discussion of the results, we met to discuss our position in relationship to common factors. We engaged in this process to acknowledge our position of support for common factors and our belief in their role as important aspects of therapeutic change; we also recognize there are significant limitations to the existing literature. Our aim was to provide a rigorous, honest, and critical commentary of the common factors literature in MFT, and we continually reminded ourselves of this aim throughout the analysis.

Bibliography: Type: Journal Article Title: Systemic family therapy can be manualized: research process and findings, Author: Pote, H.; Stratton, P.; Cottrell, D.; Shapiro, D.; Boston, P.; Journal: Journal of Family Therapy, Volume: 25, Issue: 3 Pages: 236-262 Year: 2003 DOI: 10.1111/1467-6427.00247 ISSN: 0163-4445, 1467-6427 Determining the efficacy of therapeutic interventions is becoming an increasing political and ethical necessity. Comparative therapeutic outcome trials are most powerful when there is a precise specification, or manualization, of the forms that therapies took. Manuals have begun to be developed for structural/behavioral family therapy and couple therapy. The development of these manuals is often reliant on experts' self‐report, rather than a systematic analysis of the therapeutic process as it happens. This can limit their validity and applicability to standard clinical practice. In addition, no manuals exist which reflect less structured forms of family therapy aimed at incorporating systemic, postmodern and narrative frameworks. The feasibility of producing a workable manual that reflects the fluidity of such practices has been questioned. A research project to systematically create and test such a manual is reported. Multiple data sources and research methods, primarily qualitative, were applied to generate a rich specification of the therapy. In reporting these results the contents of various aspects of the final manual are indicated. Procedures to ensure that the prescribed practice is consistent with a widely used approach to systemic family therapy are also described. The manual will be an important tool for outcome research and therapeutic practice. The account of the research process should be helpful to researchers engaged in constructing a manual for other models of family therapy based on a rigorous analysis of actual practice. The manual itself is available for use by outcome researchers who wish to evaluate this widely used form of systemic family therapy. Keywords: Need to Read There has been a tendency for the more easily specified and measurable to be privileged. It has been a common strategy for manuals to be defined and specified anecdotally by senior practitioners. These practices in manual development and outcome research may risk the development of a 'biased' evidence base. Easily prescribable cognitive-behavior techniques applied to specific diagnostic categories have been manualized before more complex psychotherapeutic techniques with more general application. Have you experienced this in your clinical work? Have you struggled to find resources or anything to provide structure to your sessions? If some therapists have more manualized theories than others, does that create a difference in outcome for clients? Are we really systemic researchers if we are only observing the individual self-report data? Are there familial/relational measures looking at more than one person in the family? How much of our understanding is the individuals that make up the system or the interactions between them? "The result is that therapists and researchers alike remain unclear about what constitutes effective family therapy." "Examples of manuals detailing less structured, systemic family therapy are limited, since until recently the ethos of these forms of family therapy has worked against anything that might look like a prescription of what the therapist should do." But have we? Therapists were required to retrospectively rate their intentions in relation to the systemic practices they observed in videotape reviews of their own therapy practice. Ratings of 26 possible intentions were given on a five-point Likert scale relating to the extent to which therapists felt they were being guided by this intention during their practice. Manuals specify different modes of clinical practice and enable comparisons of model efficacy through controlled outcome trials. In order for the findings from outcome research to be clinically relevant and meaningful, the manuals used must offer a fair representation of practices within the contexts in which the therapy is usually delivered. Within the systemic manuals that currently exist, there has been a tendency for the more easily specified and measurable to be privileged. It has also been a common strategy for manuals to be defined and specified anecdotally by senior practitioners in the field, with less reliance on therapy process research from clinical contexts. These current practices in manual development and outcome research may risk the development of a 'biased' evidence base. Across psychotherapy, easily prescribable cognitive-behavior techniques applied to specific diagnostic categories have been manualized before more complex psychotherapeutic techniques with more general application. Within family therapy the strategy has resulted in more behaviorally oriented forms being manualized and shown to be effective for specific conditions. A common criticism of outcome research is of a lack of generalizability to everyday practice. Participants are unrepresentative, as they have usually been screened to exclude any with multiple difficulties; the therapy is delivered to a higher. Standard and in more tightly defined form than is possible in normal practice; and most evidence will have accumulated about older forms of therapy. More applicable research would be facilitated by the availability of a manual derived from representative current practice, in a format that allows for current developments and the emphases of clinics in which it would be implemented. It should also be designed to consider Second-Order Change with the usual range and complexity of family difficulties. Family therapy is effective when compared with no treatment controls and, for some presenting difficulties, is more efficacious than individual interventions (e.g. marital distress, anorexia in young adolescents). Family therapy may also have advantages over individual treatments in relation to engagement and client ratings of satisfaction. Family therapy may also be more cost-effective than residential and inpatient treatments, but may not be sufficient in itself to address a variety of severe disorders and problems (e.g. schizophrenia, adolescents’ conduct difficulties). Systemic psychotherapy research is full of methodological flaws. Design issues, such as small and sometimes unrepresentative participant samples and the lack of credible no-treatment and alternative treatment controls, continue to undermine the conclusions of the research. It is easy to become lost in the multitude of definitions of what constitutes the family therapy interventions assessed, if, that is, the researchers have defined the interventions at all. The result is that therapists and researchers alike remain unclear about what constitutes effective family therapy. Examples of manuals detailing less structured, systemic family therapy are limited, since until recently the ethos of these forms of family therapy has worked against anything that might look like a prescription of what the therapist should do. The key stages in the research process Semi-structured interviews with five expert family therapists, with qualitative and quantitative analysis. Observational ratings of fifteen videotapes of expert family therapy sessions, using a specifically developed observational rating schedule and employing quantitative analysis. Development of a draft manual. Trial of the manual in practice by three experienced family therapists to obtain qualitative feedback and ascertain quantitative self-report of adherence. Semi-structured interviews were conducted by the first author with five expert family therapists from LFTRC. An adapted version of the Brief Structured Recall (BSR) method was used to structure interviews. Therapists were required to retrospectively rate their intentions in relation to the systemic practices they observed in videotape reviews of their own therapy practice. The process used to elicit accounts of the kinds of therapeutic practice the therapists would report when confronted with samples of their own practice. Ratings of 26 possible intentions were given on a five-point Likert scale relating to the extent to which therapists felt they were being guided by this intention during their practice. Using the BSR method, therapists were also asked to comment on the theoretical ideas that were informing their practice. Through this recursive process the following guiding principles were produced: Systems Focus: In working systemically the central focus should be upon the system rather than the individual, particularly in relation to the difficulties and issues that the family system brings to therapy. Connections and Patterns: In understanding relationships and difficulties within systems it will be important for the therapist to consider the connections between circular patterns of behaviors within systems. This process of therapy should enable family members to consider these connections from new and/or different perspectives.
Circular Causality (Circularity): Patterns of behavior develop within systems, which are repetitive and circular in nature and also constantly evolving.
Social Constructionism: Meaning is created in the social interactions that take place between people and is thus context dependent and constantly changing. The negotiation of a shared meaning, constructed afresh in each conversation, takes precedence over the concept of a single external reality. Strengths and Solutions: the therapist should take a non-pathologizing, positive view of the family system, and the current difficulties they are struggling with. The therapist should attend to the strengths and solutions in the stories that the family system brings to therapy. Cultural Context: The therapist should consider the importance of context, in relation to the cultural meanings and narratives within which people live their lives, including issues of race, gender, disability, religion, and class. The relationship between these narratives, the therapeutic relationship and its context, as well as the wider context for the therapeutic team and the family, should be an important consideration at the point of referral and throughout the therapy. Co-Constructed Practice: In therapeutic interactions reality is co-constructed between the therapist (and team) and the people with whom they meet. Reflexivity: Therapists should aim to apply systemic thinking to themselves and thus reject any thinking about families and their processes that does not also apply to therapists and therapy. In order to use self-reflexivity it will be necessary for therapists to be alert to their own constructions, functioning, and prejudices. Narratives and Language: behaviors and beliefs form the basis of stories or narratives, which are constructed by, around, and between individuals and the system itself. The language that is used to describe these narratives and the interactions between individuals construct the reality of their every day lives.
Power: The therapist should take a reflexive stance in relation to the power differentials that exist within the therapeutic relationship, and within the family relationships.
Constructivism: The idea that each person constitutes an autonomous meaning system and will interpret and make sense of information from this frame of reference. The systemic family therapy methods outlined through this process were: Teamwork, including the use of a designated ‘secretary’ from the therapy team to communicate with the family pre-therapy; Communications between the therapist, team and family through earbugs and telephones; Structuring sessions and feedback from the team through breaks and reflecting team discussions; Videotaping therapy sessions; Consultations to the wider system before and during therapy; Use of reading seminars to develop team thinking. Systemic family therapy techniques were more varied, with nineteen classifications including circular questioning, externalizing the problem, tracking life events and paying attention to language used. The categories were simplified for the purposes of a coding system, and the final categories were grouped into four sections: Therapist’s intention – the intervention that the therapist was observed to be attempting to implement, for example, reframing. Family trigger event – the immediate actions of a family member before the therapist event, for example, talking about the problem. Therapist techniques – the type of therapist event, for example, the use of a statement or circular question. Content of the discussion – the overall theme of the therapist and family interaction for each therapist speech act, for example, talking about solutions. Findings showed that therapists used different types of technique according to the kind of intervention they were intending to achieve.
The technique which therapists used most frequenrly was asking linear questions, though they often used these in a circular fashion, moving around the family to vuild up a picture of events from everyone's persepctive. More complex intentions were associated with Circular Questioning, and statements were used to clearly distinguish team and therapists' ideas.

Bibliography: Type: Book Title: Advanced Methods in Family Therapy Research: A Focus on Validity and Change, Editor: Miller, Richard B.; Johnson, Lee N.; Publisher: Routledge, Location: New York, Year: 2014 ISBN: 978-0-203-08452-6 Research is vital in moving the field of family therapy forward, but the myriad of possibilities inherent in working with systems and individuals can overwhelm even the most seasoned researcher. Advanced Methods in Family Therapy Research is the best resource to address the day-to-day questions that researchers have as they investigate couples and families, and the best source for learning long-term theory and methodology. The contributors of this volume share their wisdom on a wide variety of topics including validity concerns, measuring interpersonal process and relational change, dyadic data analysis (demonstrated through a sample research study), mixed methods studies, and recruitment and retention. The volume contains one of the most detailed descriptions of data collections and covers interviewing, using questionnaires, and observing brain activity.  Also addressed are suggestions to meaningfully reduce cultural bias, to conduct ethical research, and, in the Health Services Research chapter, to examine interventions for clients in various income brackets. A separate, ground-breaking chapter also addresses psychophysiological research in a couple and family therapeutic context. As an added benefit, readers will learn how to become informed consumers of journal articles and studies, how to produce quality, publishable research, and how to write fundable grant proposals. Each chapter provides a clear and detailed guide for students, researchers, and professionals, and as a whole Advanced Methods in Family Therapy Research advances the field by teaching readers how to provide evidence that marriage and family therapy not only relieves symptoms, but also effects behavioral change in all family members. Few studies have included information about how other members of the system change in relation to a single individual. The more traditional forms of statstical methods do not allow for multiple members of the same system to be included in the same analysis. family-theory-i-(8874)/lecture/1.-introd.title: 1. Introduction
family-theory-i-(8874)/lecture/1.-introd.description:
In many contexts, the term 'couple' has replaced 'marriage' because of its emphasis on the bond between family members/individuals. This shift in language is important - taking a non-judgmental approach. There is a social value implied by the more traditional terms (which privileges marriage). Use the most inclusive term possible (e.g., family) With respect to all types of relationships, use the term 'couple' as it broadly encompasses those within a committed relationship (regardless of marital status). With respect to persons of various gender identities and sexual orientations, use the term 'partner' rather than gendered language (whenever possible). While the terms such as spouse, wife, husband, boyfriend, girlfriend may be preferred by clients - intentionally using the term 'partner' may be more inclusive. With respect to those we serve, we will refer to them as clients as opposed to patients (whenever possible). Psychiatrists are physicians whoo specializes in the diagnosis, treatment, and prevention of mental health and emotional problems. (M.D. needed) Psychologist study the human mind and behavior. (Masters needed) Social Workers help people function the best way they can in their environment, deal with their relationships, and solve problems. (Bachelors degree needed, unless clinical social work which needs a masters level degree) Counselors assist people with personal, family, educational, mental health, and career decisions and problems. (Masters needed) All: Diagnose Individual/relational intervention Psychiatry Diagnose Prescribe Psychology Assessment Intra Marriage and family Therapy Family intervention Inter Social Work Case management A family's patterns of behaviors influences the individual and therefore may need to be a part of the treatment plan. In CFT, the unit of treatment isn't just the person - even if only one person is 'the client'; it is the set of relationships in which the person is embedded. Brief Solution-focused Specific with attained therapeutic goals Designed with attainable therapeutic goals Designed with the 'end in mind' MFTs treat a wide range of serious clinical problems including: Depression Relationship issues Anxiety Biopsychosocial-rooted problems Research has shown that CFT is as effective or more effective than standard individual treatments for many mental health problems including: Schizophrenia Affective Mood Disorder Substance (Ab)use Child Conduct Disorder Anorexia Autism Chronic Illness Couple/Partner Distress Psychiatry raised concern about scope of practice Wanted to keep MFTs from diagnosis Psychology sought amendments to the scope to place restrictions on psychological testing, and some oppose licensure in general. Social Work concerned with title restriction Wanted to call its members MFTs Counselors (ACA) historically most active opponents Opposed MFT licensure all together Labeled the discipline as a subspecialty of counseling Professionals from many different disciplines may at times utilize family-based interventions, or work from theories or models that are core to the CFT discipline. Does that mean they are CFTs? Profession vs. Practice AAMFT's response 'It's not our intent to define the standards or the scope of practice of any other discipline - social work or psychology, for example, by saying what services they can perform or what training is need to perform those series. "We assume those professions will be diligent in ensuring that their practitioners will only deliver services for which they have had training, and are competent to perform, and that the regulatory boards for those professions will police those who go beyond their competence." Classic Schools Bowen Strategic Family Therapy
Jay Haley Depathologize problems by viewing them as normative life-cycle complications. Consider possible adaptive functions for the family. Acknowledge the helpful, alberit misguided, intentions of individuals within a family to help one another. In such reformulations, new solutions can more readily become apparent.
Structural Family Therapy
Salvador Minuchin No family style is inherently normal or abnormal. Whether organizational patterns are functional or dysfunctional depends largely on their fit with the family's developmental and social demands. The strength of the system requires clear yet flexible boundaries and subsystems for the ability to shift organizational patterns to accommodate needed change.
Experiential Family Therapy
Virginia Satir
Carl Whitaker
Psychoanalytic Family Therapy
Cognitive-Behavioral Therapy (CBT) Developments
Contextual Therapy
Solution-Focused Therapy Focus on solutions (i.e., what works), future-oriented. Focusing on exceptions (i.e., those times when the problem was not present). Direct toward building solutions rather than increasing insight into punitive maladaptive psychological mechanisms.
Narrative Therapy
Michael White
David Epston Families have good intentions and neither want nor need problems. Families can develop empowering stories when separated form their problems and constraining cultural beliefs. Redirect focus from causal assumptions of dysfunction to appreciate the toxic effects of many dominant discourses in the social world. Others
Internal Family Systems (IFS) Therapy Evidenced-based treatments Couples
Emotionally Focused Couples Therapy
Gottman Therapy Relationship Education there Marital Preparation Multi-group Couples Therapy Does family therapy work? Therapeutic processes (e.g., how it works) Therapeutic outcomes (e.g., what results) How large are the effects of family therapy in terms of their impact on families? Are these effects sometimes negative? What are the efficacy and effectiveness of different models of family therapy? What therapist and family factors predict responsiveness to treatment? Is family therapy helping in treatment individual problems? What interactional patterns or characteristics of the family? How healthy and satisfied is the family? How did the relational patterns develop? How are they maintained? Risk factors for family functioning? How do cultural and contextual factors (e.g., age, gender, identity, class, race, etc.) play into the family's functioning? How has the family adapted to transitions, change, and crises? Frequency, setting, and duration of symptoms? Who besides the family is included in the problem? Are psychotropic medications being used? Are individual sessions held? And under what conditions? Co-therapists? Is therapy time limited? How long does it last? How often are sessions? What is the therapist's role? Consultant? Teacher? Healer? What is the role of the therapist-couple alliance? How is a working alliance fostered? To what degree does the therapist direct sessions? How does the therapist direct sessions? How does the therapist handle escalations? Do clients talk to one another or the therapist? Do clients talk to one another or the therapist? Does the therapist use self-disclosure? What are the limits? Does the therapist's role change during the course of therapy? What are the treatment goals? How are the goals determined or prioritized? Who determines the goals of therapy? How are 'mixed agendas' handled? How structured are therapy sessions? Pacing or rhythm? What techniques are used to join with the family? Is psychoeducation included? Is homework included? If secrets are revealed individually, how are secrets handled? What are the common errors that a therapist can make? How is termination determines and handled? Why is family therapy important? Why might clients choose family therapy over other approaches (i.e., individual, couple, group therapy)? When might family therapy be preferred to other treatment modalities? Under what circumstances or presenting problems might family therapy be most appropriate? What is your assessment of the problem? What is the presenting problem? Who is defining it? How is it defined? Who is the identified client? How does each member of the family view the problem? Do they share the defition? What solutions have been attempted? What are the family's beliefs, values, and cultural strengths for dealing with the problem? Reaction to psychoanalytic traditions Research on schizophrenia Acknowledge of family and contextual factors in mental illness Adoption of systems theories 1920s Group Therapy Movement 1940-1950
The Child Guidance Movement (1940s-1950s) 1950s Communication and role theories 1970s Brief therapy theories Therapists first encountered families as adversaries. Therapists begin to notice that often when a client got better, someone else in the family got worse, almost as though the family needed a symptomatic member. Clients improved in the hospital only to get worse when they went home. Parents sometimes use their children as a buffer to protect themselves from intimacy/ I.e., You're scratching your eyes for your mother so she'll have something to worry about. You're a good boy. Good children sacrifice themselves for their parents. I.e., Minuchin: As a father of a child in danger, what you're doing isn't enough. Father: What should I do? Minuchin: I don't know. Ask your son. Groups dynamics are applicable to family therapy because group life is a complex blend of individual personalities and properties of the group. The process/context distinction in group dynamics had a major impact on family therapy. Attend to how family members talk as much as to what they say. Family members have a long history and a future together. Continuity, commitment, and shared distortions all make family therapy different from group therapy. Concluded that the real problem wasn't a child's symptoms, but rather the tensions in the family that were the source of those symptoms. Tendency to blame the parents, especially mothers (this was an evolutionary misdirection that haunts the field). We need to understand the family in order to diagnose problems. Many do not distinguish between couple and family therapy. Couples therapy is just family therapy applied to a particular subsystem. However, there is a case to be made that couples therapy is a distinct enterprise (see Gurman texts) For many years, therapists resisted the idea of seeing clients' families in order to safeguard the privacy of the therapeutic relationship. Converging developments in the 1950s led to a new view that the family was an organic whole. What they observed was that the behavior of schizophrenia fit with their families; what they concluded was that the family was the cause of schizophrenia. Champions of family therapy challenged the assumption that schizophrenia was a biological disease. Psychological healers everywhere cheered. Unfortunately, we were wrong. The observation that schizophrenic behavior seems to fit in some families doesn't mean that families caused schizophrenia. Families of schizophrenic members suffered for years from the assumption that they were to blame for their child's psychoses. Modern Model Events and Timeline 1942: Founding of the American Association of Marriage Counselors 1945:
Ludwig von Bertalanffy presents General Systems Theory 1950s: Intergenerational
Family Systems Theory
Contextual Therapy
Psychoanalytic Family Therapy
Experiential Family Therapy
Brief Strategic (Mental Research Institute (MRI)) 1960s:
Structural Family Therapy
Satir's Growth Model (Human Validation Process Movement) 1970s: Founding of the American Association for Marriage and Family Counselors Strategic (Milan)
Strategic (Jay Haley) 1978: Founding of the American Association for Marriage and Family Therapy Post-Modern Model Events and Timeline 1980s
Emotionally Focused Couples Therapy Feminist Models Collaborative Language Systems Solution-Focused Therapy 1990s Integrative Couples Therapy
Internal Family Systems (IFS) Therapy
Narrative Therapy Solution-Oriented Therapy Multiculturalism 2000s Managed care/ empirically validated treatments To understand this better, consider the example of a mobile. When you move any one piece of a mobile, all the other pieces move too. They do not exist in isolation from one another, and movement in any one part of the system will affect all the rest of the parts of the system. The study of feedback mechanisms in self-regulating systems.
Feedback Loop: The process by which a system gets the information necessary to maintain a steady course. If you see behavior persist over time, there is likely something maintaining that behavior. Feedback loops can be negative or positive.
Negative Feedback: Indicates that a system is straying off the mark and that corrections are needed to get back on track.
Positive Feedback Reinforces the direction a system is taking. What shows up as one individual's behavior may be a product of the relationship. Family therapists use concepts to describe how people in a relationship contribute to what goes on between them (e.g., pursuer/distancer; overfunctioning/underfunctioning) At the core, the theory is about: Structure Functioning The whole is greater than the sum of its parts. Mapping sequences of interaction (which reveal how a system works)
Homeostasis: The self-regulation that keeps the system stable Families tend to resist change, which explains why so many clients remain stuck despite heroic efforts to improve. A system is, 'Any entity maintained by the mutual interaction of its parts.' A system can be composed of smaller subsystems. Every system is a subsystem of larger systems. Open vs. Closed systems Unlike machines, families change when necessary to adapt to new circumstances.
Social Constructionism: Seeing the world through a pair of glasses.
Reframing: Relabeling behavior to shift how family members respond to it. The goal of therapy shifted from interrupting problematic patterns of interaction to helping clients find new perspective on their lives. When they said reality was constructed, they meant socially constructed. Interpretations are shaped by our context. Interpretation of our experience mediates behavior. Social constructionists place more emphasis on the intersubjective influence of language and culture. Therapy becomes a process of deconstruction, freeing clients from the tyranny of entrenched beliefs. Inherent in most forms of therapy is the idea that before you can solve a problem, you must figure out what is wrong. But solution-focused turns this assumption on its head. The best way to solve problems is to discover what people do when they are not having the problem. Exceptions to a complaint. Therapists create a shift in their clients' experience by helping them reexamine how they look at things.
Externalization: Redefining problems not as properties of the individuals who suffer them, but as alien oppressors. The focus of therapy has expanded toward the wider context. This process started when therapists looked beyond individuals to their families. Suddenly unexplained behavior made sense. Early on, family therapists focused on behavioral interactions surrounding problems. Next, they recognize that those interactions were manifestations of a family's underlying structure. Structure became the target of change. Later, family structure was seen as the product of multigenerational processes that were governed by belief systems. Then, therapists aimed their interventions at those underlying beliefs. More recently, it dawned on therapists that those belief systems do not arise in a vacuum Behavior is shaped by transactions we don't always see. Systems concepts help make complex interactions predictable.
Family Structure: Defines the organization within which interactions take place. Interactions shape structure, but once established structure shapes interactions.
Subsystems
Boundaries
Family Life Cycle Context: People are products of their context. Behavior is powerfully influenced by interactions with other family members.
Circular Causality: Problems are sustained by an ongoing series of actions and reactions.
Triangles Process/Content Focus on the process of communication (how people talk), rather than the context (what they talk about) The goal is to get an overview of the presenting problem and arrange to meet. Listen to the description of the problem and identify all members of the family, household, and others who might be involved. Establish connection and engagement. Ask how the problem is affecting other members of the family. You'd like to hear from everyone, at least initially, in order to get as much information as possible. Reminder calls help increase likelihood of attendance. Build alliance with the family. Develop hypothesis about what is maintaining the presenting problem. Establish rapport. Gather information. Introduce yourself. Orient the family to the therapy room (physical or virtual) and the format of sessions. Invite family members to speak one at a time. Give everyone a chance to be heard. Establish a bond of understanding with each member of the family.
Process: How did you feel about coming in? What were your reactions to coming in? Take a family history. Conduct the genogram to diagram the family network. Listen for family life cycle transitions. Search for strengths and resilience. Remain curious and respectful. Explore the process of family interaction by asking questions about how family members relate to one another and inviting them to discuss their problems with one another in session. What is keeping the family stuck? Share recommendations for treatment. What is maintaining the problem? Maintain therapeutic alliance. Listen to and acknowledge family members' points of view. Through empathic understanding, family members feel respected and become open to being challenged. When one person is presented as the problem, challenge linearity by asking how others are involved or affected? What role do others play in creating or maintaining the problem? How have they responded to it? Challenge unhelpful interactions by pointing out patterns that seem to be keeping the family stuck. The more you do X, the more they do Y - and the more you do Y, the more they do X. Listen to people's feelings. Listening is a silent activity, rare in our time, even among therapists. Family members are not likely to reconsider their assumptions until they've been heard and understood. Help family members deal with one another more effectively in session. Take a less active role and encourage family members to interact more with one another. Step back and observe. When family members address their conflicts directly, they tend to become reactive; anxiety is the enemy of listening - help them listen and manage anxiety. Stay calm: You are not responsible for solving the family's problems. Just look for the constraints that are keeping them stuck. Be curious. Display empathy and respect. Review the therapeutic relationship. Say goodbye. Reinforce progress. Review what the family has accomplished. Anticipate and plan for upcoming challenges. How will you know when things are heading backwards? And what will you do? How will you know if it is time to come back to therapy? Check-in with the family following treatment, if possible. The presenting problem Understanding the referral route Identifying the systemic context Stage of family life cycle Family structure Communication Substance use/abuse Domestic violence and sexual abuse Affairs/infidelity Cultural context (race, ethnicity, culture, gender identity, sexual orientation, class, disability, etc.) Explore the presenting problem. Explore attempts to deal with the problem. What have they tried? What has been helpful? What hasn't been helpful? Has anyone who is not present been trying to help or hinder? Who referred the clients and why? What are their expectations? What expectations have they communicated to the family? Is participation voluntary or mandated? Who recognized the need for treatment? What other agencies are or will be involved with the case? Obtain a clear understanding of the interpersonal context of the problem. Who is in the family? Are there other important figures in the life of the problem who aren't present? Family of origin, immediate family, extended family, family of choice, etc. Are there other agencies involved? What is their input? Does the family see them as helpful? Remember that family therapy is an approach to people in context. Family problems become entrenched because they are embedded in powerful but unseen structure. What is the family's structure? What are the subsystems?
What is the nature of Boundaries between the subsystems?
What Triangles are present? Assess for substance use, IPV, and affairs. Consider assessment tools if needed. Be aware of mandated reporting. General Practitioner What is your scope of practice? Specialist Do you specialize in particular populations? Or problems? Most family therapists assume their approach can be applied to any problem. Of course their may be exceptions. The whole is greater than the sum of its parts. Systems can be viewed in terms of hierarchy, organization, and subsystems. Systems strive toward self-preservation and therefore its members work in service of the system, as well as themselves. All behavior makes sense in context. No one family member is responsible for the family's distress. Family therapists work to see the big picture. Even when a client presents with an individual issue (e.g., depression, anxiety), family therapists view it within the larger relational context. Share the following assumptions: A person's lived reality is relationally constructed. Personal identity and individual symptomology are related to the social systems in which they are embedded. Changing one's language and description of the problem alters how it is experienced. Truth can be determined only within relational contexts. Systems theory Systems metaphor A family is a system, a group of individuals who coordinate meaning and their understanding of the world. Social constructionist Textual metaphor People narrate their lives to create meaning using the social discourses available to them. Skeptical of objective reality. Reality is constructed. Reality is constructed through language. Reality is negotiated through relationships. Shared meanings coordinate social action. Founded upon the logical-positivist assumptions of an external, knowable truth. Therapist assumes expert role. Therapist is an expert who assumes the primary responsibility for identifying problems and goals, often assumes the role of a teacher or mentor. Theory and research are the primary sources of information for identifying problems and diagnosis. Therapist uses theory and research to select treatment approaches. Humans are essentially good. All people naturally tend toward growth and strive for self-actualization. Focus on treatment is the subjective, internal world of clients. Therapeutic interventions target emotions with the goal of promoting catharsis (release of repressed emotions). A supportive, nurturing environment promoted therapeutic change.
Examples such as Carl Whitaker and Virginia Satir One cannot communicate; all behavior is a form of communication. An individual's behavior and symptoms always make sense in context.
All behaviors and symptoms serve a purpose within the system, allowing the system to maintain Homeostasis. No one individual controls behavior in a system and therefore no one individual can be blamed for problems in the family. Problematic behavior emerges from the interactions between members of the system. Therapeutic change involves altering the interaction patterns within the system. Objective truth can never be fully known because it must always pass through subjective and intersubjective filters. The human mind does not have access to an outside reality independent of human interpretation. Knowledge and truth are culturally, historically, and relationally bound. Personal reality and truth are shaped by language and relationships. Language affects how identity is shaped and experienced. The identification of the problem is a social process that occurs through language. Therapy is a process of co-constructing new realities. As therapists become more aware of theories, they learn to skillfully integrate ideas from other approaches in a way that is philosophically congruent with their own approach. However, therapists who are 'eclectic' or 'integrative' in a way that is not grounded in a single philosophical set of assumptions will confuse their clients. Clients will be confused if each week the client is required to relate differently to the therapist and to assume a different level of participation (i.e., sending contradictory messages). If the therapist is able to keep the philosophical assumptions consistent throughout therapy, then the therapist can adapt concepts and techniques from other approaches without sending conflicting messages. Standard I: Responsibility to Clients Non-discrimination, informed consent, multiple relationships, reporting, abuse, referrals, non-abandonment, consent to record. Standard II: Confidentiality Limits to confidentiality, releases, access to records. Standard III: Professional Competence and Integrity Competency, conflicts of interest, records maintenance, harassment, exploitation, gifts, scope of practice, misconduct. Standard IV: Responsibility to Students and Supervisees Exploitation, confidentiality Standard V: Research and Publication Protection of participants, informed consent, right to withdraw, confidentiality, publication, authorship, plagiarism. Standard VI: Technology-Assisted Professional Services Teletherapy, consent, confidentiality, location of services and practice, training Standard VII: Professional Evaluations Forensics, testimony, competence, informed consent, avoiding conflicts, child custody, professional opinions Standard VIII: Financial Arrangements Disclosure of financial policies, recovery procedures, bartering Standard IX: Advertising Professional representation, affiliations, educational credentials, qualifications National

Reviews of psychotherapy outcome research document the empirical evidence supporting the effectiveness of psychotherapy. Wide range of presenting problems. Diverse therapeutic approaches Therapeutic is effective. Treated families fare better than untreated. We need to evaluate the evidence t - What is the typee of evidence? - Targeting what outcomess? - For whom? Technical/model factors “Influential Figures in CFT History.pdf” could not be found.

family-theory-i-(8874)/lecture/2.-strate.title: 2. Strategic Family Therapy
family-theory-i-(8874)/lecture/2.-strate.description:
Strategic grew out of Gregory Bateson's project on Schizophrenia at the Mental Research Institute (MRI). The initial emphasis was on observation and research on families, but due to the influence of Milton Erikson's work, intervention strategies were also formulated. Believed in using the resources of his clients and designing a 'strategy for each specific problem' He did not care about perspective (insight) as long as their actions produced beneficial results. Conducted therapy by paying extreme attention to details of the symptoms his clients presented. In therapy: Accepted and emphasized positive Used indirect and ambiguously worded directives Directed routine behaviors so that the resistance is shown through change and not through normal continuous actions. The MRI Pioneers:
Don Jackson
Gregory Bateson (As a consultant)
Virginia Satir
John Weakland
Jay Haley
Paul Watzlawick
Richard Fisch
Jules Riskin Strategic Therapy is any type of therapy where the therapist initiates what happens during therapy and designs a particular approach for each problem. Strategic therapy isn't a particular approach or theory, but a name for the types of therapy where the therapist takes responsibility for directly influencing people. Families often perpetuate problems by their own actions. Directives tailored to the needs of a particular family can sometimes bring about sudden and decisive change. The exchange of multilayered messages between family members define their relationships. Interrupting vicious cycles that occur when attempts to solve problems only make them worse. People are always communicating. All behavior is communicative. One cannot not communicate. All messages have report and command functions Report = Content = information = (What is said) Command = Process = underlying relationship = How it is said If no one registers a complaint, there is no problem. Patterns (e.g., quiet detachment, volatile engagement) may be dysfunctional for some families and adaptive for others. The approach is non-normative and complaint-based. Focuses on identifying and interrupting 'ironic processes' which occur when repeated attempts to solve a problem keep the problem going or make it worse. The aim of therapy is simply to resolve the presenting complaint as quickly and efficiently as possible, so clients can get on with life BSCT makes no attempt to specify what constitutes a functional or dysfunctional family relationship. The therapist attends to what clients do, as well as how, they view the problem, themselves, and each other. Often see family members individually in the context of family therapy, even when the focus of the intervention is a relational complaint. The model is called 'Strategic' because the therapist intervenes to interrupt ironic processes deliberately, on the basis of a case-specific plan that sometimes includes counter-intuitive suggestions Go slow Engage in behavior they want to eliminate What matters is the extent to which interaction patterns based on attempted solutions keep a complaint going or make it worse. The problems clients bring to therapy persist only if they are maintained by ongoing current behavior of the family. If problem-maintaining behavior is appropriately changed or eliminated, the problem will be resolved or vanish, regardless of its nature, origin, or duration. How a problem persists is much more relevant to therapy than how the problem originated. The persistence of the problem depends mainly on social interaction. The behavior of one member of the family is stimulated and shaped by the response of the others. How a family goes about trying to solve a problem usually plays a crucial role in perpetuating it.
Well-intentioned yet ironic solutions break the vicious cycle (Positive Feedback loops) that maintain an impasse.
Families are stuck in a spiraling Positive Feedback loop. They make common-sense but ineffective attempts to change responses. For example: When a younger sibling arrives, the older sibling, feeling unloved, starts screaming for attention. The parent punishes him which reinforces his feelings of being unloved, and he continues to throw tantrums.
Family Rules: The rules or regularities of family interaction that operate to preserve family stability.
Homeostasis:
The conservative aspect of family systems (similar to Cybernetics concept of Negative Feedback)
Circular Causality
Feedback Loops
First-Order Change
Second-Order Change
Hierarchical Structure
Prescribing Ordeals Rules are typically unspoken, and govern most behavior When tules promote rigid attempted solutions, it isn't just the behavior but the rule needs to change.
When a specific behavior within a system changes (First-Order Change)
When the rules of the system change (Second-Order Change) Rules are changed through reframes. Centerpiece of the model Families encounter many difficulties over the course of their lives, whether a difficulty becomes a problem depends on how fmaily members respond to it. Families often make misguided attempts to solve their difficulties and, on finding that the problem persists, apply more of the same attempted solutions. This produces an escalation of the problem, which provokes more of the same, in a vicious cycle. What often needs to happen? Reverse the solution!
Paradoxical Injunction:
A technique used in Strategic Family Therapy whereby the therapist directs family members to continue their symptomatic behavior. If they conform, they admit control and expose secondary gain; if they rebel, they give up their symptoms. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019) Not to point out that an individual is fighting going under, but instead tell the individual to keep their eyes open until they become unbearably heavy.
Reframing: Changing the interpretation.
Identify Feedback Loop s that maintain problems. Determine the rules that support those interactions. Find a way to change the rules in order to interrupt problem-maintaining behavior. Do not regard any particular way of functioning, relating, or living as a problem if the client is not expressing content with it. How problems develop: Cybernetic:
Difficulties turn into chronic problems by misguided solutions, forming Positive Feedback escalations. Structural: Problems are the result of incongruous hierarchies. Functional: Problems result when people try to protect or control one another covertly, so that their symptoms serve a function for the system. Once the presenting problem is resolved, therapy is concluded. If a family didn't ask for help with other issues, they aren't targeted. The job is simply to get the family moving again. Help families define clear and reasonable goals so that everyone knows when treatment has been successful. In pushing family members to set concrete goals, they are forced to clarify vague dissatisfactions. The primary goal is behavior change. Alter specific patterns of communication that maintain problems.
Mental Research Institute (MRI): The way to resolve problems is to reverse the misguided solutions that have been maintaining them.
Jay Haley: Changes in behavior alter perceptions (rather than the other way around) Milan: Get families to see things differently (through reframing or positive connotation), rather than in getting family members to behave differently. Define a resolvable complaint. Obtain a very specific behavioral picture of the complaint. Who sees it as a problem? Why is it a problem now? "What is the problem that brings you here today?" is too vague. Inquire about exactly what these complaints mean. Identify attempted solutions that maintain the complaint. Once the problem had been defined, the therapist tries to determine who has tried to solve it and how. The solution is part of the problem. Prescribe some alternative behavior! The key is to stop the performance of the problem-maintaining solution. MRI Approach: Introduction to the treatment setup Inquiry and definition of the problem Estimation of the behavior maintaining the problem Setting goals for treatment Selecting and making behavioral interventions Termination Attempted solutions: The solution is deny that a problem exists; action is necessary but not taken. For instance, parents do nothing necessary despite the growing evidence that their teenage son is using drugs. The solution is an effort to solve something that isn't really a problem; action is taken when it shouldn't be. For example, parents punish a child for masturbating. The solution is an effort to solve a problem within a framework that makes a solution impossible; action is taken but at the wrong level. For instance, a husband buys gifts for his wife when what she wants is affection. Solutions that perpetuate problems fall into three categories: When clients deny that a problem exists (example: anorexia) ACT When clients try to solve something that really isn't a problem (example: punishing a child for masturbating) STOP ACTING When clients try to solve a problem within a framework that make a solution impossible (example: husband buys gifts for his wife, rather than giving her the affection she desires) DIFFERENT ACTIONS Understand the clients' unique language for describing the problem. To interrupt problem-maintaining sequences, therapists may try to do something that runs counter to common sense. Paradoxical interventions: The therapist directs the family members to continue their symptomatic behavior. If they conform, they admit control and expose secondary gain. If they rebel, they give up their symptom(s). Most common symptom prescriptions where the family is told to continue or embellish the behavior they complain about. Hope is that the family will comply and then be forced to reverse their attempted solution. May also hope the client rebels against the therapist's advice. Restraining technique: Warning clients against changing to fast and relapse; reinforced the therapist's one-down position. The family is told to continue or embellish the behavior they complain about. Sometimes the therapist prescribes the symptom while secretly hoping the clients will rebel against the directive. As soon as a family member is overwhelmed, they are instructed to make a list of all the things that they might do to sabotage their life. Doing so can take the rebellion out of self-destructive behavior, thus making it less appealing and less impulsive. Asking a couple to deliberately have an argument during the week in order to help the therapist understand how they get involved in such no-win encounters and how they are able to get each other to act unreasonably. Discouraging families from trying to change too fast, warning them to go slow and worrying out loud about the possibility of relapse when improvements do occur. Perhaps you should continue to wake Ricky up for school, after all, you don't want to push him to be too responsible too soon. The main thing is to discover what families are doing to perpetuate the problem and then get them to do something different. Co-founded the Family Therapy Institute of Washington D.C. (1974) Hayley learned from:
Milton Erikson
Gregory Bateson
Salvador Minuchin
He adopted and modified Milton Erikson 's individual emphasis to work with families. Concerned with the function a symptom served.
Examined rules and structure of a family (influenced by Salvador Minuchin). Hayley was particularly concerned with power struggles, and often prescribed the symptom such that the cost of keeping it up outweighed the gains. Madanes was concerned with incongruence hierarchies, where a child uses symptoms to change the behavior of the parent. Family Life: Over and covert rules families use to govern themselves
Family Homeostasis: Tendency of the family to remain in its same pattern of functioning unless challenged to do otherwise.
Quid Pro Quo: The responsiveness of family members to treating others in the way they are treated.
Redundancy Principle: Fact that a family interacts within a limited range of repetitive behavioral sequences.
Punctuation: Idea that people in a transaction believe what they say is caused by what others say.
Symmetrical Relationship s: Relationships within a family are both among equals (symmetrical) and unequals (complementary).
Circular Causality: Idea that one event does not 'cause' another but that events are interconnected and there are multiple factors behind a behavior. To resolve, remove, or ameliorate the problem the family agreed to work on. Behavioral, concerned with the immediate problem, and anti-insight. Structural re-organization of the family, like the structural therapies, but with sub-goals to deal with the presenting problem. Process, not content-focused. Emphasize short term treatment (10 sessions) Define a problem clearly Investigating all solutions that have previously been tried Defining a clear and concrete change to be achieved Formulating and implementing a strategy for change Therapists must be innovative Therapy must be customizable to families (technique driven) If families are going to change, alterations in ways their members act must precede new perceptions or feelings Focus on interpersonal payoff of psychiatric symptoms Social Stage: Introduction and setup Help everyone relax, greet each family member, make sure everyone is comfortable. Problem Stage: Definition of the problem in clear behavioral terms Ask each individual for their perspective, speak to the less involved parent/partner first to get their involvement, listen carefully to the way each family member describes the problem, make sure no one interrupts until each has a turn, make observations. Emphasize the use of directives. If therapy is to end well, it must begin proper. Interaction Stage: Estimation of the behaviors maintaining the problem Encourage family members to discuss their points of view among themselves, observe rather than just hearing about the interchanges that surround the problem, look for coalitions between family members against others, how functional is the hierarchy and do family members work together as a team or undercut one another? Goal Setting Stage Providing directives Give the family a task, directives Offering a different perspective/framework to understand problem behavior. "The use of language to give a new meaning to a situation." For instance, a child's misbehavior can be reframed as his way of asking for attention, not an indication of disrespect. Reframes can be offered by asking circular questions: "Who makes you depressed?" "What does dad do when you and mom are fighting?" Changing the frame of reference for understanding behavior leads to change in the rules governing interactions which in turn leads to sustainable change. Where a symptom is often seen as a metaphor for an underlying problem. Example: A school problem in a child may mirror a work problem in a parent. Mandanes talked about how one relationship may metaphorically replicate another and power struggles in couples (money, education, control of children, etc.) Negotiation (pg. 90)
Quid Pro Quo (pg. 91) Pretend techniques (pg. 91) Ordeals (pg. 91) Hayley believed that telling people what they're doing wrong only mobilizes resistance. Changes in behavior alter perceptions. Milan group was interested in getting families to see things differently through (reframe) positive connotation. Which then gets family members to behave differently. Shift from behavior to cognition set stage for constructivist/narrative movements. Families should have clear generational boundaries. Therapists should be 'neutral' and not have expectations for families. Therapy helps the family by simply examining the family, asking questions to help them examine their own family structure, and exposing games after which they can redesign their family into a better structure on their own.
Mara Selvini Palazzoli
Gianfranco Cecchin Presession: Generate initial hypothesis of presenting problem. Session: Validate, modify, and change the hypothesis. Intersession: Team discussion of hypothesis and arrival at an intervention. Intervention: Delivery of the intervention to the family. Postsession: Team discussion to analyze the family's reactions and to plan for next session. Highly scripted. Families treated by co-therapists and observed by other members of the team.
Positive Connotations Must include the entire family system and confirm the behavior of all family members as maintaining the stability and cohesion of the group.
Rituals: Engage families in a series of actions that ran counter to or exaggerated rigid family rules. Define the complaint in specific behavioral terms. Set minimum goals for change. Investigate solutions to the complaints. Concentrate on the 'less of the same.' Understand clients' preferred views. Use these views to suggest 'less of the same' Nurture and solidify initial change. Frequency of sessions intended to maximize the likelihood that change will be durable. Typically patter of brief (e.g., weekly, tapering off) Therapy ends when the treatment goals have been attained (and change seems reasonably stably?) Co-therapists work as a team (e.g., observing behind the mirror, leaving the room to consult) Late in session, the therapist may leave so the team can help the therapist plan a homework assignment or framing intervention. The essential role of the therapist is to persuade the family to 'do less of the same' solution that keeps the complaint going. Treatment is likely to go awry if the therapist is not in control of it. Good strategic therapists rarely exert control directly in the sense of offering authoritative prescriptions or assuming the role of an expert. Taking a 'one down position' and a stance of empathetic curiosity. I'm a little slow on the uptake here, so could you help me understand again what it is you do when he raises his voice that way? I don't know if doing this when he walks through the door will make much of a difference, but if you could try it once or twice this week, at least we'll have an idea what we're up against. Emapthetic restraint (e.g., go slow) is used to neutralize apprehension and resistance to change. When clients fail to follow a suggestion, a common response is for the therapist to take the blame (e.g., I think I suggested that prematurely) and seek alternative routes to the same strategic objective. While the model does not emphasize the importance of the therapeutic relationship, this does not mean that strategic therapists come across as cold, manipulative, or uncaring. On the contrary, many receive high ratings on rapport and alliance. Define a resolvable complaint. Identify solution patterns (problem-solution loops) that maintain the complaint. Understand clients' unique language and preferred views of the problem, themselves and each other. The first two goals provide a template for where to intervene and the third goal is relevant to how to intervene. Gather a specific behavioral picture of the complaint Who is doing what? If I had a video of this, what would I see? Assess who sees the complaint as a problem and why it is a problem now? Determine a minimum change goal What would you be doing, or the two/three/four of you be doing differently that will let you know this problem is taking a turn for the better. Inquire into behaviors that are closely related to the problem: What has the family is done to handle, prevent, or resolve the complaint? What happens after these attempted solutions? Develop a picture of what 'less of the same' will look like: What behavior, by whom, in what situation, will suffice to reverse the problem-maintaining solution? The key element to stopping the performance of the attempted solution, so as not to perpetuate 'more of the same' problem-maintaining solution. The final assessment goal is grasping the clients' unique views. This is crucial to the later task of framing suggestions: How do they see themselves and want to be seen by others? What do they hold near and dear? When are they at their best, and what do others notice about those times? What is their best guess about why a particular problem is happening - and why they handle it the way they do? Whose idea was it to come? Why now? Who is most optimistic that therapy will help? How will you know the situation is improving? What kinds of change will you settle for? What will need to happen (or not to happen) to let you know that, even if you are not out of the woods entirely, you're at least on the right path? What will each of you settle for? Therapeutic restraint: Telling clients to 'go slow' Cautioning them about the dangers of improvement Giving insturctions about how to make the problem worse Go slow is used to prepare clients for change, to convey acceptance of reluctance to change, and to solidify change once it begins to occur. Asking the family to collaborate in performing the problem patterns (e.g., an argument) deliberately. Identify problem-solution feedback loops: Demand-Refuse Discuss-Acoid Criticize-Defend Accuse-Deny Encourage the family to do less of the same: When members felt the need to talk about their relationship, they would first go bowling.
Reframing: For a small set of family complaints, the goal is to help families reevaluate their problem as 'no problem,' or as a problem they can live with. Acknowledging (Reinforcing): When a small change occurs, the therapist acknowledges and emphasizes the clients' part in making it happen, but avoids encouraging further change directly. Predicting or Prescribing: Exploring the dangers of movement. Therapeutic restraint / going slow Prescribing the symptom / performing the problem / predicting Jamming / experiment Reframing Less of the same Acknowledge / reinforce Critics sometimes regard strategic therapy as 'manipulative' because the therapist does not usually make the rationale for particular interventions explicit to clients. The therapist may say things that they do not truly believe to achieve an effective framing. Proponents counter that responsible therapy is inherently manipulative and that therapeutic candor can be disrespectful. Good therapy shows profound respect for clients' subjective experiences. Critics suggest strategic therapists may ignore problems such as intimate-partner violence or substance abuse, if clients do not perceive or present them as overt complaints in session. The model does not attempt at helping families with personal growth or solving underlying emotional issues. The central curative factor is interruption of 'ironic processes' which depends on: Accurate identification of the particular solution efforts that maintain or exacerbate the problem. Specifying what less of those same solution behaviors might look like. Designing one intervention that will persuade at least one of the people involved to do less or the opposite of what they have been doing. Applicable to any family that presents with a clear complaint. Particularly relevant for families that seem resistance to change. Most qualitative research (case reports) and follow-up quantitative data. Historically, most of the research on the effectiveness of Strategic Therapy wasn't very rigorous. Mostly case report format. Anecdotal support for its efficacy, although people tend not to write about their failed cases.
Case reports with Anorexia Nervosa, Schizophrenia, and delinquency (pg. 96) Brief Strategic Family Therapy for adolescent substance abuse and behavior problems Treatment engagement, family functioning Focuses on the process of communication rather than its content. Clever, prescriptive, expedient Critiqued as manipulative Therapist is responsible for the outcome of therapy. Families are stuck in well-intentioned but ineffective attempts to solve problems.
Paradoxical Injunction: To shake the status quo of the system Circular questioning and team supervision from the Milan group. Team approaches to therapy As a treatment for families, strategic differs from most other approaches in that the therapist is willing, and sometimes prefers, to see family members (particularly partners) individually.
