family-theory-i-(8874)/lecture/3.-struct.title: 3. Structural Family Therapy
family-theory-i-(8874)/lecture/3.-struct.description:
Salvador Minuchin (1921-2017) Physician in the Israeli army Trained in psychoanalysis in the US Studied interpersonal psychiatry with Harry Stack Sullivan Worked with delinquent boys at the Wiltwyck School - where foundation for family therapy was laid. Director of the Philadelphia Child Guidance clinic Why did Minuchin go into family therapy? He sees families in terms of particular shapes, particular stages He sees himself as an instrument, a challenger of patterns
Family is depicted as a system that is comprised of Subsystems A family is functional to the degree that it nurtures its members to negotiate well the demands of the outside world. Boundaries set limits distinguishing subsystems from one another in varying permeability (from diffuse to rigid). Subsystems separated by a diffuse boundary are enmeshed, whereas subsystems separated by a rigid boundary are disengaged. Family
Structure Structure is expressed through transactional patterns such as:
Hierarchy
Power Alliances
Subsystem (couple, parent, sibling)
Boundaries
Coalition
Patterns
Triangles
Loyalties The family could have developed a structure different from the dysfunctional one now being displayed. The family processes adaptive resources in its relational repertoire that currently lie dormant. Therapy attempts to activate what is already there, but latent. Offers a framework that brings order and meaning to family transactions. The consistent patterns of family behavior reveal family structure. The emotional boundaries and coalitions that make up a family's structure are abstractions. The concept of family structure enables therapists to intervene in a systematic and organized way. Families seek help for a specific problem. Family therapists look beyond the specifics of those problems to the family's attempts to solve them. Exploring dynamics of interaction. Recognizing the overall organization of the family regulates those interactions. The model attends to subsystems and boundaries that regular contact between members. The model emphasizes enactments wherein family members are encouraged to deal directly with one another in session, permitting the therapist to observe and modify their interactions. Structural family therapy provides therapists with a blueprint for how to view patterns of family dynamics.
The three major concepts of structural family therapy are Structure, Boundaries, and Subsystems.
Subsystem (Couple; Parent; Sibling) Problems are symptomatic of the family's inability to be flexible and accommodating of changing needs. All family behavior, even destructive behavior, has the goal of balancing the system to ensure its survival. Family problems do not result from stresses in the system but from the effects of reactions and responses to the stresses. Structure is: The way a family is organized into subsystems whose interactions are regulated by interpersonal boundaries. The organized pattern in which families interact Patterns are formed based on rules that are implicit or explicit. Over time, as patterns develop, roles for family members are established. Patterns are isomorphic (i.e., interaction patterns are repeated in different relationships in a system). The focus of treatment is on changing the family structure rather than changing individual family members. The process of family interaction is like the patterns of conversation at the dinner table. The structure of the family is where family members sit in relation to one another. As family transactions are repeated, they foster expectations that establish enduring patterns. Family structure is reinforced by the expectations that establish rules in a family. Families are differentiated into subsystems based on generation, gender, or function. Adults are the 'organizational leaders' of the family system so whatever is present in the adult subsystem relationship will be felt throughout the whole system. Children are common 'symptom bearers' Organization is most healthy when there are 3 clearly defined systems: Marital/Couple Parental Child/Sibling Each subsystem is demarcated by interpersonal boundaries. Boundaries range from rigid to diffuse. Defined as rules for managing physical and psychological distance between family members and for defining regulation of closeness, hierarchy, and family roles. Rigid boundaries are restrictive and permit little contact with outside subsystems, resulting in disengagement. Disengaged systems are independent, but isolated. On the plus side, this fosters autonomy. But limits affection and support. Diffuse boundaries result in enmeshment. Enmeshed systems offer closeness, but at the expense of independence. Too much closeness can cripple initiative. Determines who (or which subsystem) has power in the system. Any structure in a family is not static, it is developed over time. Hierarchies can be rigid and unfair or weak and ineffective. Be aware of cross-generational coalitions. Accommodation requires the family system to be flexible and alert to changing needs of individuals in the family. Boundary making refers to the demarcation of subsystems as they are formed. In accommodating to each other, a couple must establish a boundary between them, as well as a boundary separating them from the outside. The addition of children transform the structure of a family into a parental subsystem and child subsystem. Even in healthy families, children often bring stress and conflict. Children require different styles of parenting at different ages. Minuchin warned therapists not to mistake growing pains for pathology. What distinguishes healthy families isn't the absence of problems, but a functional structure for dealing with them. "The problem behavior is a symptom of the dysfunctional structure of the family system." Disengaged or enmeshed subsystems Hierarchies are weak and ineffective; or rigid & arbitrary Conflict avoidance Detouring which results in a scapegoat Cross-generational coalition (where hierarchy may be inverted) Modifications in structure are required when a family or one of its members encounters external pressure (a parent is laid off) or a developmental transition occurs (e.g., parents retire). Healthy families accommodate to their changed circumstances, dysfunctional families increase the rigidity of structures that no longer work (e.g., strict parenting tightening up further when a child acts out and needs nurturance). Families are susceptible to develop a dysfunctional structure during periods of: Normative life cycle transition The arrival of a first child An adult child leaving home An acute stressor Natural Disaster Unemployment Single Adult Coupling Having Children Families with Young Children Families with School-Age Children Families with Adolescents Divorce Blended Families Launching Children Later Life Early on the model shifted from why family members interact the way they do, and the past, to how they learned to act that way. Now, the model considers not only how family members interact, but also how and why they learned to do so. All behavior makes sense in context. The mechanism of change is the production of new relational experiences for families. Families change each other by behaving differently toward each other.
Enactment refers to those moments in therapy when family members interact directly with each other.
Enactment is not necessarily a technique. It typically occurs naturally in session. It is the 'here-and-now' of the therapy session. Alter the organization of a family so that its members can solve their own problems. The goal is structural change; problem-solving is a by-product. Problems are embedded in dysfunctional structures. Activate adaptive patterns that are already in families repertoires. Create effective hierarchy: Parents should be in charge, not relate to their children as equals. Differentiate individuals and subsystems by strengthening the boundaries around them. Increase contact by making boundaries more permeable. The therapist produces change by joining the family, probing for areas of flexibility, and then activating formant structural alternatives. Joining conveys acceptance of family members and respect for their ways of doing things. Only after joining can the therapist attempt restructuring. Understand the family's view of their problems by tracking their perspectives (words they use to explain problems and the behavior with which they demonstrate them).
Enactment s reveal structural patterns and later change them. Take-Away: Observe and modify the structure of family transactions in the immediate context of the session. The therapist manages the nuts-and-bolts details of how the therapy process is structured including: Who should attend How often Referrals for psychiatric evaluation Therapy aims to change how family members experience each other. Family members are expected to be present together for sessions. Relational experiences can 'wash out' between sessions, therefore, therapy usually starts out weekly. Join the family accommodate to its members' style (building alliance) Map the family structure, boundaries, and hierarchy (evaluating and assessing structure) Intervene to transform the structure to diminish symptoms (addressing the problems identified in the assessment) Observe and assess how family members respond to their dilemmas. Because problems are a function of the entire family structure, it's important to include the whole group for assessment. Some problems may be treated individually. Problems can persist in individuals, in the social context, or the feedback between them. Individual problems need to be identified and appropriate. Structural therapists prefer to begin therapy with the entire family, but they do not insist on it. Once the family has been assessed, the therapist often meets with specific subsystems and individuals to achieve structured goals. Role of the symptoms in the family
Subsystems
Cross-Generational Coalition
Boundaries
Hierarchy
Complementarity
Family Life Cycle Strengths Ask questions about the presenting problem until family members begin to see that the problem goes beyond the symptom bearer to include the entire family. Assist family members in seeing how their interactions may be perpetuating the presenting problem. Briefly explore the past, focusing on how the adults in the family came to develop the perspectives that influence their interactions. Explore options that family members might take to interact in more productive ways to create a shift in the family structure and help resolve the presenting problem. Greet the family Ask for each person's view of the problem Listen carefully Acknowledge what you hear Model empathy that family members are temporarily not able to provide Acknowledgement (feeling heard and understood) releases family members from resentment Joining opens the way for family members to begin listening to one another and establishes a bond with the therapist that enables them to accept the challenges to come. Intervention Language: Joined with the Family Engaged in Reflective Listening Built Rapport Acknowledged Reflected Summarized Validated Elicited Emphasized Challenged Reinforced Maintain an outsider perspective to remain objective, while becoming familiar with family's experiential reality. Unless therapist is allowed to become part of the new system, no change will take place. Respect the family, and its individual members, despite presenting problem (i.e., abuse) The therapist joins the system in the sense that they accommodate to its style; how people talk, what words they use, how they walk, and so forth. Make contact with each member of the family Greeting, shaking hands (pre-COVID) Using names Noticing something unique about each of the members Find something similar about each person and then allow the family members to recognize the similarity Skills involved in joining: Accommodating: Matching the family's style of language with gestures or subject matter (being 'familiar' to the family) Being interested in the family's interests (i.e., baseball). Validating: Validate the worth of each family member. Searching for Competencies: Therapist enhances self-esteem by discovering and validating competencies.
During joining, assess the Family Structure:
Hierarchy Who has the most power? The position members take in relation to each other (emotional closeness between members).
Boundaries between Subsystem Assume authority for the structure of therapy. Maintain control so things do not go awry. Lead by following. Be able to interrupt. Make demands, rather than polite, requests. Inviting the family to schedule the next session. Validating ambivalence about coming again. Need to expand family's view of problem to include all family members. Therapist is less concerned with the content of the message than with how it is transmitted, to whom, and with what effect.
Process messages usually describe the power structure of the family, Hierarchy, Boundaries, emotional tone, and Family Rules. Attending to process = accommodation when the therapist responds to the underlying affect in the manner in which the statement is made. Process comments are better when kept general. The therapist notices a problematic sequence (a hunch). The therapist initiates an enactment (talk this over with your partner). The therapist guides the family to modify the enactment (offering encouragement as needed).
Enmeshment Watch for interruptions, speaking for one another, doing things for one another that they can do for themselves, arguing.
Disengagement Watch for passivity, absence of emotion, absence of conflict, ignoring, lack of concern for other's interests. When the enactment breaks down: Comment on what went wrong. Push them to keep going. Assess interactions in session. Families tend to quickly induct therapists in their culture. Take into account both the problem the family presents and the structural dynamics it displays. Once families begin to interact, problematic transactions emerge. Recognizing structure requires focusing on process, not content. Achieve intensity by selective regulation of affect, repetition, and duration. Tone, volume, pacing, and choice of words can be used to raise the affective intensity of interventions.
Pay attention to Coalitions Temper tantrums are maintained by parents who give in. They try not to give in; they just don't try long enough.
Empathy: Use empathy to go beneath defensiveness. Interrupt squabbling and using empathy talk with each family member at a time about what they're feeling.
Shaping Competence: A particular method of modifying interaction, reinforcing positives, reinforcing use of functional alternatives already in the family's repertoire. Invite family members to speak for themselves. Block interruptions. Assist dyads in finishing conversations without intrusion. Although structural family therapy begins with the whole family, subsequent sessions may be held with individuals or subgroups to strengthen boundaries. Asking family members to change seats. Asking family members to move seats further apart or closer together or turn toward one another. Having separate sessions with individuals or subsystems to strengthen boundaries. Asking one or more members to remain silent during an interaction. Asking questions that highlight a problem boundary area (e.g., do you always answer for your son when he is asked a question?) Blocking interruptions or encouraging pauses to enable less dominant persons to speak. The goal in unbalancing is to change the relationship within the subsystem. The therapist joins and supports one individual or subsystem. While taking sides seems like a violation of neutrality, this is done to unbalance and realign the system (note that fairness is achieved because the therapist sides with family members in turn). Tools/Techniques:
Reframing
Complementarity
Intensity
Enactment The therapist sometimes challenges the way clients see things. Act as a teacher, offering information and advice, often about structural matters. Stroke and a Kick: To mother, "You are very helpful." (Stroke) To daughter, "Mommy sometimes takes away your voice. Can you speak for yourself?" (Kick) After the family's view of the problem has been enlarged by process comments and family is familiar with therapeutic process. Therapist can present the family with a different perspective of the problem that allows them to activate new behaviors (in a new situation) To formulate a reframe the therapist brings together the verbal and nonverbal messages. Should take into account every member. Should like the family problem with the rules of the structure. Should not be explained to the family. As family members describe their problems, therapists reflect on their understanding systemic reframing, which takes into account all behavior as reciprocal. Use family's language. Use family's content. Include everyone. Ensure the reframe has a nonjudgemental, non-blaming focus, and better still, has positive connotations. Be prepared to restate the reframe in several different ways. Avoid intrapsychic interpretations and why-because aspects in forming the reframe. Realize that there is no perfect reframe. Structural mapping is used as an assessment tool for understanding interaction patterns. Blocking: Stopping usual transactions. Exaggerating: Encouraging or sustaining interactions. Silence: When a response is expected, doing the unusual by not giving one - thus demanding the family to act. All unbalancing, if successful, will heighten tension and intensity to fuel family to move toward change. Actively shift the focus of the family from solving the presenting problem to changing the family structure. The therapist must unbalance the family's old patterns. The model directs therapists to look beyond the content of problems and even beyond the dynamics of interaction to the underlying family organization that supports and contains those interactions. The most important tenet in that every family has a structure, and this structure is revealed only when the family is in action. Strongest empirical support comes from a series of studies on children with psychosomatic symptoms and young adults addicted to drugs. Early structural family therapy studies demonstrated effectiveness in treating disruptive behavior and adolescent substance use. More recent, studies have shown that structural family therapy can be effective when addressing problem behavior spanning the externalizing spectrum (e.g., disruptive behavior, adolescent substance use, conduct disorder, ADHD) Treatment is concerned only with the relief of the family's suffering. Interventions are limited to relief of suffering, thus treatment may be brief (<6 sessions) Therapist must be more flexible than the family. Focused on change not insight (how not why of dysfunction). Therapist should be in charge of all communications and coordination with collaborators. The self of the therapist is one of the primary tools for facilitating change. Therapists must use themselves to relate to the family, varying from being highly involved to professionally detached (depending on the family's needs).
Salvador Minuchin encouraged new therapists to reflect on aspects of their personal and relational lives that shape their therapeutic process and client behavior in session. Describe 'who you are' as a therapist. How will 'who you are' as a therapist impact therapy with families? What are your personal strengths? What are your growth areas? Strongest empirical support comes from a series of studies on children with psychosomatic symptoms and young adults addicted to drugs. Early structural family therapy studies demonstrated effectiveness in treating disruptive behavior and adolescent substance use. More recently, studies have shown that structural family therapy can be effective when addressing problem behavior spanning the externalizing spectrum (e.g., disruptive behavior, adolescent substance use, conduct disorder, ADHD). Similar to all family therapy approaches, structural family therapy is not effective in all cases. No research identifies readily observable characteristics shared by failed cases of structural family therapy. Developed to work with poor urban families, at all socioeconomic levels, ethnic groups, sexual orientations, and across countries. Indirect empirical support, as research on efficacy has focused on applicability to family treatment. Studies that directly test structural family therapy's efficacy in the treatment of various presenting problems and targeted populations are needed. Efficacy 'refers to treatment effects observed in randomized controlled trials.' Effectiveness 'refers to treatment effects in routine practice.' Currently, the evidence does not show that any of the demonstrably efficacious approaches to family therapy are more effective than other approaches, largely because there is a dearth of evidence on the efficacy of many widely used family therapy approaches. Family therapy research has had little impact on the day-to-day practice of family therapists. The disconnection between research and practice is alarming. This may be attributed to, 'An overemphasis by researchers.. On treatment packages and therapeutic models/techniques.' Insufficient attention has been paid to sources of influence on treatment outcomes (the skills of the the therapist themselves) Effective family therapy requires a good 'fit' between the person of the therapist and their primary theoretical orientation. Family therapy is shifting to research that addresses the process aspects of the therapeutic models. It is important to remember there are multiple ways of knowing what works: Randomized control trials Case studies data Observations of therapists and clients Collecting qualitative or quantitative Remember: Research lags behind practice in family therapy. Just because a model has been tested doesn't inherently mean it is superior. Heteronormative Pathologizing (seeing problems are embedded in dysfunctional family structures) Family mapping implies pathology resides in family structure, but this is not true. Problems are viewed as a failure to adjust to changing circumstances.

family-theory-i-(8874)/lecture/4.-cognit.title: 4. Cognitive-Behavioral Family Therapy
family-theory-i-(8874)/lecture/4.-cognit.description:
Engaging and making comfortable Joining Creating alliance Building rapport Active listening Open-ended questions Identifying strengths and why now Reinforcing positives Mapping family system/ Genogram Exploring family dynamics (assessment) Reflecting Summarizing Reframing Circular questioning Acknowledge/reinforce Thoughts and perceptions Acting or behaving Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) is a form of psychological treatment that has been demonstrated to be effective for a range of problems including depression, anxiety disorders, alcohol and drug use problems, marital problems, eating disorders, and severe mental illness. Problems are based in unhelpful thinking and behavior. Families can learn better ways of coping, which improves symptoms. Behavior is maintained by its consequences. Consequences that increase behavior are reinforcers. Consequences that decrease behavior are punishers. Behavior is regulated by its consequences. Responses that are positively reinforced will increase. Responses that are punished or ignored will be extinguished. CBT/CBFT is a highly efficacious intervention to assist families in a variety of contexts (this model has empirical support) CBT has focused on family's cognitive processing and behavioral interactions, while minimizing the influences of individual differences between family members. CBT also addresses characteristics that each family member brings to their relationships, explaining why family members behave and interpret events in maladaptive ways. Scarcity of positive outcomes available for each family member. Deficits in communication and problem solving. High frequency of negative or punishing exchanges reciprocated by partners, parents, family members. Family members are more likely to track negative behavior selectively and to make negative attributions for such behavior. They reciprocate negative behavior with negative behavior. Primary distress results from unmet fundamental needs create secondary distress (withdrawal or verbally abuse among family members) Behavior is maintained by its consequences. Ratio of costs and benefits to behavior (something is maintianing it) Good relationships are under positive reinforcement ocntrol CBT recognizes the influence of both the family's behavioral interactions (processes) and the major themes (content) that serve as the basis for relationship discord. Thoughts change to promote behavioral change (thoughts -> behavior) Emotions and actions are mediated by cognitions (thoughts -> emotions) Understand cognition (beliefs, attributions, expectancies) makes it possible to identify triggers to behavioral patterns. Uncovering hidden/automatic assumptions that keep people stuck. Overgeneralizations Magnification and minimization Personalization Dichotomous thinking Labeling and mislabeling Also called black and white thinking, catastrophizing, defense mechanisms Help families become more active observers and evaluators of their own automatic thoughts, long-standing assumptions, and of their relationship standards. Individual family members vary in the extent to which they have a clear understanding of the factors affecting their relationships and clear goals for treatment and how their own contributions affect the achievement of their goals. Therapist determines the appropriate sequence of addressing goals in therapy. Extinguish undesired behavior and reinforce positive alternatives. Ignoring the tantrum; rewarding the child for putting feelings into words Redefine the family's goals of decreasing negative behavior into increasing positive responses. Families have difficulty describing the behavior they want to see more of The therapist helps by asking families to make a list of things the other person did that they liked throughout the week. Reviewing the list in session the next week provides an opportunity to emphasize the importance of positive feedback. This agenda of therapy is educational: Teach communication, problem-solving, and negotiation Behavior will change when the contingencies of reinforcement are altered. Identify behavioral goals Learn techniques to achieve these goals Facilitate social reinforcement of change Brief (about 20 weekly sessions) Use of homework assignments Phase out therapy gradually. Once the family shows evidence of substituting positive interactions for negative ones and goals are achieved. Booster sessions Collaborate with families in designing homework to complete between sessions. Homework is based on the learning principle that to replace existing ingrained dysfunctional interactional patterns with new ones, families rehearse the new patterns repeatedly, particularly under 'real life conditions.' CBFT has been popular in two primary sub-systems: All couples run into conflict. Conflict resolution is a critical skill. Healthy families are not problem free, but they can resolve conflicts when they arise. They describe their own feelings and request changes in the behavior of others rather than criticizing or complaining. Good relationships are not made in heaven, they are a product of learning effective coping behavior. Families need problem solving skills Therapy includes: Clinical interview Rating specific behaviors Relationship satisfaction questionnaires Couples are taught to express themselves in clear, behavioral descriptions, rather than in vague complaints. Couples are taught new behavior exchange procedures, emphasizing positive reinforcement. Couples are helped to improve their communication. Couples are encouraged to establish clear and effective decision-making. Couples are taught strategies to problem-solve future complaints to extend the benefits of therapy. Ask each partner to list three things they would like the other to do more often. Imagery Role-play Coaching (to switch places, to increase their empathy for one another's feelings) Communication training For example: Engaging in an argument without attacking
'I' statements (Using 'I' Statements.pdf)
Speaker listener exercises (Practice Exercise (Speaker Listener Activity)) Problem-solving training Homework assignments Mindfulness and meditation Sensate focus (p. 164) In vivo desensitization (p. 164) Parents ahve control over the rewards and punishment of children. If parents change the contingencies of reinforcement, the child's behavior will change. Skills are taught in sequence (shaping) Help parents define the child's positive and problematic behaviors in specific observable actions. Tracking target behaviors Reinforcing desired behavior through contigent encouragement with incentive charts.
Disciplinary tehcniques include Time-Out and ignoring the problem behavior. Observe/Assess the frequency of problem behavior, what precedes it, and what reinforcement follows (Behavior Chaining) Shaping (reinforcing small steps toward change)
Token Economy (reward good behavior) Contingency contracting (agreements by parents to make certain changes following changes made by their child)
Time-Out Once assessment is complete, the therapist decides which behaviors should be increased or decreased. Once effective rewards are chosen, parents are taught to shape desired behavior by reinforcing approximate behaviors. Ignoring Rewards Identifying Automatic Thoughts Assist family members in identifying automatic thoughts To improve the skills of identifying automatic thoughts, clients are encouraged to keep a diary to jot down situations that provoke the thoughts and the resulting emotional reactions. Joining with all members of the family simultaneously can be challenging. Families in conflict often desire to form an alliance with the therapist, each family member trying to convince the therapist that the other members are responsible for relationship problems. Do not be triangulated! CBFT therapists hear the seriousness of the concerns while not siding with individual family members. CBFT therapists use empathic reflective listening with one family member and then the other, followed by statements summarizing the reciprocal interwoven concerns of all members. CBFT therapists are a neutral party whose agenda is to help family members achieve their personal goals for family relationships. CBFT therapists often define relationship problems in 'dyadic terms.' Blocking (e.g., interrupting) if necessary Inclusion of other individuals if necessary Medication, and individual therapy can be used in conjunction with CBFT Co-therapy model is allowed Both individual and conjoint sessions are allowed. Clients may be more likely to divulge information about their past in private sessions. CBFT therapists tell clients they will keep this information confidential, but if it might be influencing the family's current interactions, they encourage the person to share it in a joint session Secrets Be up front with clients about the limits of confidentiality Assist them with sharing in a joint session (rather than outing them) Didactic role early on to strike a balance between directiveness and collaborationl Reviews homework assignments, model skills, coaches family members in practicing them, and fosters motivation. Balances alliances and interventions with all the family members or subsystems so that they feel supported. Sets the pace of sessions so that the goals of treatment are addressed in a timely and sequential fashion. Sets the agenda each session Monitors the use of time Responsible to stay on task and address the goals of session Teaches the clients to self monitor as well Maintains control of the session with confidence and credibility Assumes multiple roles: Director Educator Facilitator Collaborator Advocate Balances the alliance and interventions with all members, so they feel supported and invested. Primary Goals: Identify the concerns and potential areas of enrichment/growth. Clarify the cognitive, behavioral, and affective factors associated with family members, dyadic subsystems, and the family environment. Determine the appropriateness of family therapy Including each family members' level of commitment and goals for treatment. Information gathering: Self-report questionnaires, clinical interviews, observation of interactional patterns Initial conjoint interviews: How the couple met, what attracted them to each other, how they developed a deeper involvement, positive and negative life events, prior experiences in therapy. Inquires about the family members' current concerns and strengths of the relationship. Orients the family to the process of therapy by describing the structure and course of CBFT and the roles of therapist and family. Increasing the frequency and magnitude and positive behaviors Love days Date night Departing with a kiss "Work together with the family to develop a series of agreements on how they want to make changes in their relationships to meet the needs of the family members, to help their relationship function effectively, and to interact positively with their environment." (Gurman et al., 2015, p. 36) For sharing thoughts and emotions (p.38) For listening (p. 38) For decision-making conversations (p. 38) "The therapist provides the family with instruction in the use of particular behavioral skills, through didactic discussions and/or other media (e.g., readings, videos). The instruction is followed by opportunities for the family to practice behaving in the new ways." Selective Attention What each person notices about the partner and the relationship Attributions Inferences about determinants of relationship events Expectancies Predictions of what will occur in the relationship in the future Assumptions What each person believes people and relationships actually are like Standards What each person believes people and relationships should look like Socratic Questioning Understanding the underlying issues through evaluations of the logic of thinking Guided Discovery Clarify each person's standards. Discuss advantages and disadvantages of existing standards. If standards need alteration, help revise them to form new acceptable standards. Problem solve how new standards will be taken into account behaviorally. If partners standards continue to differ, discuss ability to accept differences. Normalize emotional experiences, positive and negative Clarify thoughts, then relate these to emotions Use questions, reflections, and interpretations to draw out primary emotions Describe emotions through metaphors and images Discourage attempts to distract the self from experiencing emotions Encourage acceptance of the individual's experience by family members For example, asking one family member to recount a particular incident in detail while helping the individual enrich their expression in a way that helps the individual and the family. Schedule times to discuss emotions and related thoughts with your partner/family member Practice 'health compartmentalization' Seek alternative means to communicate feelings and elicit support Tolerate distressing feelings Roles become familiar and predictable Knowledge and skill deficit Reluctant to change due to being hurt in the relationship Intimate partner aggression Infidelity Individual psychopathology Health problems Obsessive-compulsive disorder Anorexia nervosa Widely evaluated Found to be efficacious for distressed couples and families and improving relationship functioning Effective in alleviating distress and improving communication Effects have been found in relatively brief interventions (lasting 8-12 weeks) Finding generalize across continents with experienced and student therapists Most families appear to maintain gains in relational adjustment for up to 1 year.

family-theory-i-(8874)/lecture/5.-soluti.title: 5. Solution-Focused Therapy
family-theory-i-(8874)/lecture/5.-soluti.description:
Steve de Shazer
Insoo Kim Berg Miracle question Rating/Scaling (1 to 10) Break After intermission, the therapist will give the client/family compliments, sometimes followed by a suggestion or homework. If it ain't broken, don't fix it. Once you know what works, do more of it. If it doesn't work, don't do it again, do something different. Solution-focused family therapy begins with clients' descriptions of how they want their lives to be different. It can be understood as beginning with the end of the story, rather than the beginning of the problem. The basic idea is to avoid escalating problem talk by instead focus on eliciting movement in a helpful direction (i.e., focusing on solutions). Focus is on solutions, on what works for clients. Respect clients own resources. Directed toward building solutions rather than increasing insight into punitive maladaptive psychological mechanisms. Future-oriented Focusing on those times when the problem was not present (exceptions). The task of therapy is to do something different. What is happening in your lives that you want to continue to have happen? The most fundamental difference between the emphasis between problem-focused therapy and solution-focused therapy is the emphasis each give to the concept of 'solution.' Solution-focused family therapy seeks to identify exceptions to the problem and develop new solutions that work. What brings you in? What are your best hopes for this meeting? Therapists avoid diagnostic categories and preconceived notions of what may be healthy or unhealthy. Accept the client's version of what is, and what is not, the problem. It isn't necessary to know what causes problems in order to make things better. Families that come to therapy are capable of behaving effectively, but their effectiveness has been blunted by a negative mind-set. The model draws attention to forgotten capabilities, which release families from preoccupation with their failures and restores them to their capable selves. Problems are seen as overwhelming because families see them as always happening, times when problems are not happening, aren't noticed, or are dismissed. People are constrained by narrow views of their problems that perpetuate rigid patterns of false solutions. The meanings people attribute to behavior limit the range of alternatives they will use to deal with a situation. Changing the way people talk about their problems. The language of problems tends to be different from the language of solutions. Problem talk: Negative Focuses on the past Implies permanence of problems. Clients are experts in their own lives. Clients know what they need Is there anything else I should have asked you or that you need to tell me? The therapist needs to know how to set aside their own frame of reference as much as possible and explore those of their clients. People are resourceful. Problems are normal life-cycle complications. Families have the abillity to construct solutions that can enhance their lives. Solution-focused therapists steer families away from speculating about problem formation. Problems persist in the way people define situations and in the misdirected actions they persist in taking. Set clear goals and build on exceptions to problems. Good therapy is more than implementing specific techniques, it also involves therapeutic alliance. The goal of solution-focused therapy is to resolve the presenting problem as expeditiously as possible. The goal is not about how families should be structured, but only what they want different in their lives. The model emphasizes the importance of assisting clients in creating well-defined goals, framed in positive terms and modest enough to be achievable. What will you be doing instead? The model works by helping clients amplify exceptions to their problems – effective solutions already in their repertoire. Changing the way people talk about their problems is all that needs to be accomplished. As the family and therapist talk more and more about the solution they want to construct together, they come to believe in what they are talking about. It is easier to get people to talk differently about their problems than it is to get them to change their behavior. Getting people to talk positively will help them think positively and ultimately act positively to solve their problems. Change perception helps with the change of behavior. As a picture of positive future develops, the family begins to see themselves differently and they respond to what they see. They begin living in the solution, not the problem. The 'virtuous cycle' gets going, the family gets unstuck, and they move forward. Time limited Sessions are made one at a time One may be enough Typical course includes 3-5 sessions Clients can return as-needed Often a week to a few weeks apart Once you know more of what works, do more of it Gather a brief description of the presenting problem. Move to directly asking clients about how things will be different in their lives then their probelms are solved. Ask about times in the clients' lives when their problems do not happen or are less severe. What do you think the problem is now? How will you know when the problem is solved? How will you know when you don't have to come here anymore? What will the signs be? What will have to be different about others involved in the situation? What is your wildest fantasy about what you want to happen? What would it take to get your family member (or the court) off of your back? Takes little intake information because they want to hear clients' constructions of their problems firsthand (in session). Asks more about perceptions than feelings. Affirms clients' positions by conveying understanding of their point of view. Doesn't function as an expert; clients are experts on what they want to change. Takes an active position in moving clients away from worrying about their predicament and toward steps to solution. Anyone who is concerned about the problem should attend sessions and are part of the solution. Consultant Guardian of the conversation Don't get bogged down in 'problem talk' Focus on what is right Direct clients away from the problem-saturated narrative. Therapist attempts to create a context for the family to develop more useful ways of responding. Focus on the 'here and now' The future provides a blank canvas on which the family can paint a picture of their wishes and hopes. Assumes a position of 'not knowing.' What needs to happen as a result of coming here so that afterward you will look back and be able to say it was a good idea? What needs to happen as a result of coming here so that this will not have been a waste of your time? Often in our experience, we have found that in between scheduling an appointment and coming in, something happens that contributes to making a problem better. Has anything happened to improve the problems that brought you here today? Constructing a more detailed description of the therapeutic goal. Once a description of the goal has been developed, the therapist asks the client to assess their current level of progress toward

family-theory-ii-(hdfs-8875)/lecture/3.-.title: @cordovaAcceptanceChangeInterventions1998
family-theory-ii-(hdfs-8875)/lecture/3.-.description:
Bibliography: Cordova, J. V., Jacobson, N. S., & Christensen, A. (1998). Acceptance versus Change Interventions in Behavioral Couple Therapy: Impact on Couples’ In-Session Communications. Journal of Marital and Family Therapy, 24(4), 437–455. https://doi.org/10.1111/j.1752-0606.1998.tb01099.x Type: Journal Article Title: Acceptance versus Change Interventions in Behavioral Couple Therapy: Impact on Couples' In-Session Communications, Author: Cordova, James V.; Jacobson, Neil S.; Christensen, Andrew; Journal: Journal of Marital and Family Therapy, Volume: 24, Issue: 4 Pages: 437-455 Year: 1998 DOI: 10.1111/j.1752-0606.1998.tb01099.x ISSN: 0194-472X, 1752-0606 Integrative Behavioral Couple Therapy (IBCT) attempts to improve Traditional Behavioral Couple Therapy (TBCT) by incorporating an emphasis on promoting acceptance into TBCTs emphasis on behavioral change. This study examined changes in couples' communication over the course of IBCT and TBCT. Early, middle, and late sessions were coded to measure couples' communication of acceptance. Results showed that IBCT couples expressed more nonblaming descriptions of problems and more soft emotions than TBCT couples during late stages of therapy. IBCT couples significantly increased their nonblaming description of problems and significantly decreased their expressions of hard emotions and their problematic communication over time. Results support the hypothesis that structural differences between the therapies affect initial levels of emotional expression in session. Increases in nonblaming descriptions of problems were significantly correlated with increases in marital satisfaction.
Keywords: #Research Purpose: The purpose of the current pilot study was to investigate whether these two different approaches to couple therapy lead to theoretically predictable differences in couples’ in-session communication processes.
“Integrative Behavioral Couple Therapy (IBCT) attempts to improve Traditional Behavioral Couple Therapy by incorporating an emphasis on promoting acceptance into TBCT emphasis on behavioral change.” (Cordova et al., 1998, p. 1)
“IBCT couples expressed more nonblaming descriptions of problems and more soft emotions than TBCT couples during late stages of therapy. IBCT couples significantly increased their nonblaming description of problems and significantly decreased their expressions of hard emotions and their problematic communication over time.” (Cordova et al., 1998, p. 1)
“Structural differences between the therapies affect initial levels of emotional expression in session. Increases in nonblaming descriptions of problems were significantly correlated with increases in marital satisfaction.” (Cordova et al., 1998, p. 1)
“Integrative Behavioral Couple Therapy, developed by Andrew Christensen and Neil S. Jacobson” (Cordova et al., 1998, p. 1)
“an emphasis on promoting acceptance into the traditional emphasis on overt behavioral change.” (Cordova et al., 1998, p. 1-2)
“IBCT suggests that fostering acceptance is an essential step toward improving couples’ relationships.” (Cordova et al., 1998, p. 2)
“TBCT suggests that effective skill building is not only necessary but sufficient for ameliorating distress.” (Cordova et al., 1998, p. 2)
“TBCT is primarily a skill-building approach to treatment. It is designed to quickly and effectively teach distressed couples the skills thought to be necessary for improving the relationship and maintaining those improvements over time.” (Cordova et al., 1998, p. 2)
“Behavior exchange focuses on teaching partners to identify those things they do that are pleasing to each other and instructs couples in the utilization of those behaviors as a means of improving the quality of the relationship. Communication and problem-solving training focus on teaching partners specific techniques useful in facilitating effective communication and problem definition and resolution. Communication training teaches partners the effective use of I messages and active listening as well as the clear distinction between the speaker’s role and the listener’s role. Problem-solving training teaches specific steps to be followed in the process of solving a problem, including problem definition, brainstorming solutions, selecting workable solutions, solution contracting, and solution testing.” (Cordova et al., 1998, p. 2)

family-theory-ii-(hdfs-8875)/lecture/3.-.title: 3. Behavioral Family Therapy
family-theory-ii-(hdfs-8875)/lecture/3.-.description:
Linear thinking: Behavior is based on previous consequences. Major Tenet: Behavior is determined by its consequences more than its antecedents. Types of conditioning: Classical Conditioning
Operant Conditioning Big Picture: Behavioral Family Therapists are less likely to talk about how families develop and/or operate. They are concerned about the present, and how the problem is being reinforced. Symptoms: Although they are reluctant to do so, Behavioral Therapists have delineated what distinguishes a 'healthy family' and a 'dysfunctional family' (pg. 69-74 and 97-104 in FT Handbook chapters) Mutually shared goals and expectations. Support for the stresses associated with the expected transitional life stages, and other stressful life events. Mutual influence, that is positive more than negative.
Boundaries (more implicit by separating family into dyads) Tolerance for Deviance Skills in conflict resolution Adaptability Flexibility The ability to change when necessary The goal of treatment is to change the problem behavior by changing the consequences of it, or the contingencies of it. Techniques Use of Self
Parent Training: Intervention begins with an assessment of the target child's behavior. The goal of the assessment is to get a baseline of the behavior so that you can quantify change. Functional Analysis of Behavior: Once the problem behavior is identified, then the antecedents and consequences surrounding the behavior are explored. (stimuli, organismic variables, target behavior/response, consequences, contingencies). Report the assessment to the family. Intervene in the pattern. Step 1: Induction (teach the lingo) Step 2: Demonstration (show them how it works) Step 3: Implementation (contingency contracts, time-out, star charts, marble game, etc.) Generalization: The goal is that this training will be generalized to other behaviors, but booster sessions are also helpful. Alexander and Parsons (1982) created for troubled adolescents and their families. Incorporates cognitive aspects and takes a more systemic approach, while the goal is behavioral change. Integrates three perspectives: Ecological Learning Theory Cognitive Two Phases of Treatment Therapy: Designed to modify attitudes, assumptions, expectations, labels and emotions of the family. The major focus is to relabel (reframe) the problem behavior into something positive. Education: Help family behave differently in conjunction with reattributions. Resistance to treatment is considered an impediment to change. It is a natural consequence of the inappropriate application of technology and failure of the clinician to understand the meaning of the behavior. Functional Family Therapy relabels behaviors to reduce resistance and to motivate change by providing reattributions for the causes of family members' behaviors. Change in meaning is a necessary precursor to behavior change. The relabeling (reframe, positive connotation, etc.) operates at three levels: Interactional Level: Benign description of the interpersonal impact of the behavior (distance regulation) Motivational Level: Recasts the motive for the behavior in a benign light. Systemic Level: Emphasizes the similarities between people, a family theme. If the reframe works it interrupts automatic processing, interrupts the behaviors that follow from this processing, and thus, changes the contingencies around the problem behavior. Functional Family Therapy emphasizes paying attention to the interpersonal functions of behaviors: Functions: A person's pattern of behaviors, feelings, and thoughts mediate amounts of psychological relatedness in a relationship with another person (distance regulation) The expression of the function can be labeled good, bad, or neutral, the function itself is not judged. These functions are properties of relationships not traits. Linear Thinking: Cognitive processes need to be incorporated, although some would argue that they were never eliminated in the first place (i.e. cognition is a behavior). Meanings of behaviors, attribution processes, belief sets, automatic thinking can get in the way of contingency change. Unit of analysis tends to be the dyad: Behavior therapists have moved toward more contextual assessments, but each move out focuses on the one to one relationship rather than the system as a whole. Dependency on the therapist? Therapist teaches the model. Based on postivism Not postmodern, it is modern. Politics of behavioral couple therapy, acceptance.
Same process as parent training. Assessment is always first. Social Exchange Theory viewpoint. Could include couple discussing an issue in the room, with therapist observing communication patterns. Also includes evaluating the relationship itself (pg. 106-107). Strengths Major complaints Sex life (affection) Future goals Alternatives to the relationship Individual functioning of each spouse Intervention: Once assessment is complete you set goals with the clients, focusing on one problem (well defined) at a time, this comes in the form of a contract. Major Goals: Increase positive control while decreasing aversive control. Improve communication, which should facilitate future problem solving. Interventions: Active listening with behavioral descriptions of the problem Teach new behavior exchanges Encourage couple to establish clear and effective means of sharing power and decision making. Teach strategies for future problem solving Techniques: Caring Days Make a list of what your partner could do to make you feel cared for. The partner does not need to do anything in return. Do not include sex as it can be seen as coercion. Quid Pro Quo Contracts Not very common because we get into the standstill of 'they have to do it first' Good Faith Contracts Both partners engage in those behaviors whether their partner does or does not. Politics and Power Politics of Behavioral Couple Therapy (i.e. Jacobson) Jacobson saw the issue with classic BMT as a problem with power, who gets to say what needs to change? IBCT was developed from these concerns, the focus shifted to acceptance and forgiveness. IBCT Deep Analysis: D Key differences between partners in personality, interests, goals, etc. E Emotional sensitivities or vulnerabilities that each partner brings to the relationship (create a vicious cycle) E External circumstances (i.e., stressful circumstances which could exacerbate the problems created by differences and vulnerabilities) P Patterns of interaction that couples get into as they try to navigate what comes from DEE above. Intervention based on the idea that all relationship problems result from the combination of a triggering action or inaction and a sensitive reaction. They suggest that relationship problems can be resolved by altering the triggering action and the vulnerable response (emotional acceptance). Empirical support for the model in both clinical trials and efficacy research.

family-theory-ii-(hdfs-8875)/lecture/4.-.title: @byng-hallRewritingFamilyScripts1995
family-theory-ii-(hdfs-8875)/lecture/4.-.description:
"We may feel secure enough to explore if we can predict that support will be readily available if and when it is needed, especially if new ventures run into trouble or if potentially dangerous situations arise. Difficulties that lead to consultations with a family therapist often arise out of conflict within the family's own relationships."
"The family script can provide routines for family life which can be followed almost automatically."
"Repetition becomes the background against which change is the foreground, that which is new becomes the focus of attention. In contrast, chaos obscures potentially significant change, unless the new behavior facilitates consistency, in which case that new patter becomes the foreground, thus becoming the new center of attention."
"Rewriting family scripts follows the sequence of a scripted pattern giving way to some improvisation followed by the establishment of a new pattern."
"Family scripts can be defined as the family's shared expectations of how family roles are to be performed within various contexts." The term 'expectations' implies anticipation of what is to be said and done within family relationships, as well as family pressures to perform the roles as expected. If one member fails to perform in the prescribed way, another member of the family may be recruited to take up that role instead. The plot is 'scripted' while the cast can change. Family scripts are revealed when repeating patterns of family interaction are either observed or described.
Family Scenario: An encounter of which it can be said that something significant happens within family relationships. Basic elements of family scenario: Context Families engaging with each other around a particular task or situation Plot Family members 'motives' become clear as the scenario unfolds Outcome The consequences of the encounter are revealed The expected scenarios for each particular family situation thread together to create an overall script for how all family relationships are expected to be conducted in general. "Problem Scenarios": Instead called 'Attempted Solution Scenarios' This helps us to focus attention on how each person tries to solve the problem. The behavior that is experienced now as problematic may have started out as an attempted solution to an earlier problem. The co-constructed story may then become part of the family beliefs about what to expect of itself. Improvising implies abandoning the set script and extemporizing instead. This may happen when the old script does not fit the current situation, or when those involved are in sear of something different.
The therapist can help to create a new co-constructed scenario by suggesting a goal which the family then achieves in their own way. Suggest a scenario in which it becomes necessary for the family to improvise. (in two parent families, the parents should devise a strategy together)
Try to block each move that has not worked in the past. Unraveling some of the origins of the scripted scenarios frees families to explore new pathways. Work on the present and the past can reinforce each other. Replicated Scripts Parents with their own individual scenarios from childhood that are repeated Corrective Scripts Choice of the opposite style of parenting Improvised scripts Corrective scripts repeated over time The therapist's background also plays a part in shaping scenarios in therapy. Positive Labeling Can be given to replicative scrips by labeling them as being loyal to the family of origin. Corrective scripts can be given a positive frame by pointing out to parents that they are struggling to provide a better experience for their children than their parents were able to provide for them. Improvised scripts (unlike the historical replicative and corrective scripts) are written in response to current situations. They are improvised either out of necessity or driven by curiosity and a wish to explore new ways of relating. A stimulus for improvisation is a degree of uncertainty about what to do next so that interaction must be played off the cuff. Positive comments can be made about how much the family is exploring unknown territory. Attachment behavior The behavior of a person seeking proximity to his or her attachment figure in a potentially dangerous situation. (This is a mechanism that protects children - or adults - when vulnerable)
The child uses the parent as a safe base from which to explore, and parent and child stay in contact to ensure that they can get together in the presence of any potential danger. In terms of script theory a potentially threatening situation evokes tightly scripted behavior in which parent and child predictably got together. Exploration allows for more improvisation. The therapist can become a temporary attachment figure to the family. The therapist must be aware of the factors that threaten the family's relationship. Any new behavior of uncertain origin emerging in a relationship (e.g., unexplained impatience) might be seen as either strange and treated as potentially dangerous, or novel and will arouse curiosity. If it is perceived as strange, attempts may be made to avoid reprovoking the impatience, returning to old familiar ways instead. If the impatience arouses curiosity, then it will probably lead to trying to discover what it is all about, and to improvise ways of dealing with it. If it becomes clear that the impatience poses a problem and something has to be done about it, new solutions may be improvised out of the necessity to sort things out. There are two main forms of improvisation in family relationships: Improvisation that comes out of necessity (Something has to be done when old solutions are not working)
Improvisation out of curiosity when it feels safe to try something new, even if it is uncertain where it will lead. A therapist who is trusted by the family can make the risks involved in improvisation feel less frightening, even when family relationships are insecure.

Transgenerational Continuity and Discontinuity: Replicative, Corrective, and Improvised Scripts
Positive Framing of Replicative, Corrective, and Improvised Scripts

family-theory-ii-(hdfs-8875)/lecture/4.-.title: 4. Psychoanalytic Models of Family Therapy
family-theory-ii-(hdfs-8875)/lecture/4.-.description:
Most psychoanalytic models are based on Freud's idea around the identity, ego and super ego, or the development of self. For Freud the drives were sexual (in terms of possession and control), for newer psychoanalytic ideas the drives are more around connection and validation of the self (good or bad).
Object Relations Theory in some ways provides a bridge between psychodynamic theory and systems theory. We relate to people in the present based on expectations formed by early experience. Normal Development (?) Early development is based on attachment theory/separation-individuation constructs. Infant is born ready to be in a reciprocal relationship. This is activated by relating to a parent, by being loved and loving. Stages of development based on object relations: internal object (mental image of self and other, and self in relation to other). Objectless (primary narcissism/autistic) there is no other, only self. The following stages focus on the development of self through relations with internal and external objects: first the actual interactions and then the unconscious residue of the interactions. As humans, we exist in the context of relationships not as single units: There is no self without an object, there is no object without a self. Infants develop in a context of concentric 'holding environments.' As infants internalize the guarding, protecting, soothing and nurture of this 'holding environment' they begin to form a self (even if the environment is inadequate).
These early experiences then form our 'unconscious' drives for connection or separation. 'Real' others are 'used' to satisfy those drives, and we find others to validate our sense of self (good or bad). Health: achieving and preserving psychic wholeness through good object relations, integrating our 'unconscious' with our consciousness. Self and its relationships with others rest on and are expressed by the degree to which relations between the self and object are gratifying (but some theorists would suggest that since we are so narcissistic in the beginning, the relationships with others are never gratifying enough. Is it possible to be healthy?) Fairbairn suggest that as we internalize objects we are inevitably disappointed by them, in order to defend against this pain, we do the follow: We split off those aspects that are too painful to be tolerated.
Repress these intolerable aspects. This modifies the ego. Pathology occurs when some aspects of the repressed self-object system are excessively repressed, leaving the central self depleted with an impoverished relationship to the 'ideal object.'
Other forms of pathology occur when the central self system is taken over by one of the usual repressed systems, such as those whose relations are characterized by continual patterns of distance and rage with the apparent disappearance of reality. Fear-dictated flight from early object relations is also considered the deepest root of psychological problems. Skynner (1981) Diffuse boundaries
Unclear identities
Satisfaction from fantasy as opposed to reality
Difficulty coping with separation and loss
Attempts to preserve past states of relationships
Attempts to manipulate others into rigidly held views of them The major goal of Object Relations Theory is to free family members of unconscious restrictions so that they will be able to interact with one another as whole, healthy persons on the basis of current realities rather than unconscious images. The encounter between the therapist and client is the intervention. The relationship is the crucible for change and growth. The therapeutic process is the same as 'normal development' during infancy. The therapist provides the holding environment, contains/introjects the clients' emotions, resolves them, understands them, somehow makes them acceptable, and then the client introjects the resolution of the emotions. Therapist projects back a 'corrective experience.'
Self of therapist is key: Transference and counter-transference are the keystones of any psychoanalytic therapy, meaning the therapist must constantly be aware of who they are' for the client, and who the client is for them. Change occurs through insight and working through. Techniques: Listening
Empathy
Interpretation and maintaining neutrality with respect to what or how things change Big Picture (how families operate/develop): He uses attachment theory as a base. Early attachment relationships create 'working models' of how relationships are supposed to be, they create 'scripts.' as people interact with each other to become a family, they create their own 'family script' based on these early 'working models.' families have attachment patterns that are full of meanings about abandonment, engulfment, intrusion, etc. (i.e., distance regulation)
These scripts provide routines for family life which can be followed automatically. They are shared expectations of how family roles are to be performed within various contexts.
These scripts may be carried out from generation to generation in one form or another. Some use replicative scripts (repeat what has happened in the past), while others use corrective scripts (trying not to repeat scripts from the family of origin). There is a constant tension between these two. Healthy vs. Dysfunctional families Healthy families have scripts that provide a set of roles with which each member can identify and which provides room for improvisation when facing new situations. These scripts promote interactional awareness: Consequences of interaction
Self-awareness (why you are acting in a particular way)
Empathic awareness (why others are acting in particular ways)
Understanding the meaning of the interaction
Shared coherent perception of what is happening Symptoms occur when there is difficulty updating scripts. They may occur because the script necessary remains someone or something too painful to relive. Intolerable information is blocked or edited both intraphysically and interpersonally (secrets)\
Symptoms may also occur when a family script is used to prevent what members may fear to be an even worse disaster. Even though the current script is painful, it is rigidly clung to (the solution has become to problem) Major goal is improvisation (flexibility). In order to create an environment safe enough to explore options however, the therapist must provide a secure base from which to explore. Paradoxically, scripts, although repetitive, provide the background against which change can occur. Attachment notions Secure
Curious
Improvisation
Uncertainty
Insecure
Avoid strangeness
Stick with the familiar Instead of conflict in the family arising out of one person's pathology which extends to influence another's behavior, family scripts are encoded in all family members' minds, but each family member plays a particular role. Therefore, each member of the family can be taught to see how their role contributes to the problem, rather than asking the 'sick one' to reown the bad object and working through these issues. Reduce strategies that undermine problem-solving abilities (i.e., triangulating, scapegoating, etc.)
Reduce strategies that undermine security (threats about leaving, control, etc.)
Move toward collaboration rather than coercion and blame. Re-edit scripts so the roles are fillable by the individuals in the family. Move closer to an ideal script in which a wide scope of improvising is possible. Develop a hopeful script. Promote ownership of family's success, attributable to them not you as the therapist. This is still important for the therapist to attend to. The therapist needs to contain the family's emotions in a way so as not to become another player in their script. Therapists own scripts can also be replayed, thus it is essential that the therapist understand their own family script. Byng-Hall outlines methods for staying out of the script and for containing emotional impact: Staying out: Use teams, get supervision, have a clear plan, use circular questioning
Containing: Reflecting on the process, seeing emotions as valuable information, differentiating your script from the family's, share your emotional experience with the family. Absolves people of responsibility for their behavior (it is my mother's fault)
Lack of empirical testing
Tautological thinking: Make an interpretation, it is rejected, patient is resistant, you must be onto something. Perspective is individualist or dyadic without revision. Deterministic, linear thinking (it is my mother's fault)
Blaming the victim (you put yourself in this situation, because of what your mother did)
Mother blaming
Long process

family-theory-ii-(hdfs-8875)/lecture/6.-.title: 6. Contextual Family Therapy
family-theory-ii-(hdfs-8875)/lecture/6.-.description:
Ivan Boszormenyi-Nagy Biological and historical context variables (i.e., sex at birth, national origin, race/ethnicity, etc.) Also, events that you had no control over (parents divorce, illnesses) Anything that would impact how families function. Cognitions, affect, perceptions, experience, individual coping mechanisms. Could include attachment styles here or other psychodynamic constructs Patterns of interaction between family members.
Concepts of family systems theory (Boundaries, Family Rules, Triangles, Differentiation of Self, etc.) could be included here. This is the cornerstone construct for Nagy's work. Trust Loyalty (split, invisible) Entitlement (destructive) All of these influence justice and fairness in relationships and are transmitted through generations. Ontic: 'I-Thou' relationship, or dialogue Revolving Slate, justice and fairness All humans have worth and should be provided with 'due care.' When we don't get the care we deserve we develop symptoms We develop destructive entitlement which continues the cycle. Multidirected partiality Acknowledgement/accountability/crediting Exoneration Therapist use of self: you need to believe/live the theory and examine your own entitlements. Family Transaction & Power Relational Fairness/Ethical Dimension Ontic Facts Psychology Dimension II: Strong emotional reactions (anger, shame) Behaviors (control-seeking or chaotic/risky) Nay point to a destructive entitlement. As humans, we are born with value and are entitled to do care. When we do not get that, we develop a destructive entitlement. We seek others to meet our needs. We treat our partner as an object rather than a person in a relationship. Dimension III (Transactions): Rigid or chaotic structures Power struggles High conflicts Conflicts over 'nothing' Violation of trust Destructive entitlement Parentification Parent using the child to get the parents do care needs met. Overgiving Over functioning, one of the partners decides what is wrong and how to fix it. They decide what is wrong with the other person and how they need to fix it. Getting into someone else's lane. Not making 'claims' People not claiming self. People not holding themselves accountable. Loyalty conflicts or its 'invisibility' Restoring trust and balance of fairness in relationships Opening relational resources Opening a dialogue about fairness Direct address Presenting options Enhancing an individual's capacity to consider the needs of others and acknowledgement of their acts Enhancing an individual's capacity to stand up for his/her own needs and to do self-validation through acts Earned merit and due consideration = balance Not neutral Multidirected Partiality Not being neutral, being multidirectedly partial that you acknowledge each person's perspective and saying 'I get it. I understand why you may think that way.' You want the couples to learn how to validate someone else's perspective. Not agreeing with it, but just expanding the ability for a person to have compassion for others. Getting couples to ask for what You have been with me long enough you should know. Opening up of relational issues. People cannot be in a relationship and give nothing. Keep looking for their contribution. Want couples to validate each other and themselves. As people acknowledge that other people make contributions (due consideration), we feel that we are getting the due consideration. For couples therapy - considering Transitional Nonjudgmental Facilitating - 'sowing seeds and opening doors' and giving moratorium But - therapy still can be 'short-term' Avoids becoming parentified Therapists' own relational histories may resonate with those of their clients 'Self-of-the-therapist' issues may prevent clinicians from keeping a balanced stance towards members of the family Therapist does not need to be liked by their clients. Why is it so important that your clients like you? Should your clients get better for you to be a good therapist? Child maltreatment Blended families Adoption and foster care Couple relationships Anger issues Depression Self-esteem Self-destrucitve behaviors and substance abuse Multirectional Partiality Acknowledgement Crediting Anticipatory Listening Direct Address of Fairness Issues Suggestions Summary/Interpretations Making Accountable Exoneration Beginning Safety and trust Middle Dialogue and relational ethics End Integration/solidifying constructive entitlement Establish safety and trust Alliance building Assess on 4 dimensions Facts, individual psychology, family transactions, relational ethics Acknowledge past - identify transgenerational revolving slates Screen for risk factors and ethical/legal issues Emphasize strengths rather than pathology Relational Ethics and Dialogue Behavioral changes Mutual listening and validation skills Develop effective dialogue skills Make explicit relational ethics, i.e., power imbalances, broken trust Make explicit issues involving family-of-origin Destructive entitlement Split loyalties Deparentification Exoneration Integration: Solidify constructive entitlement Reinforce in calm environent Balance give and take Enhanced trust Continue work with exoneration Highlight new strengths and resources plan for the future De-escalation and soothing Acknowledgement of the other: Of reality, points of view Deeds Good starting point: "Do you see any truth in her/his words" Acknowledgement of the self (instead of 'why') Claiming considerations Repairing past unfairness Exploring family of origin model of fairness Creating a couple's new fairness: Repair and negotiation How did your childhood experiences shape your model of what you owe and deserve and your beliefs about love and fairness? Does love in your family permit you to question what's unfair? (p. 108) How does your unfinished business play out in your expectations of yourself and your partner? (pg. 112) What did your parents appreciate about you? (pg. 127) What happened when you protested unfairness (pg. 133) Parental accountability and responsibility Restoration of fairness between generations of adults (parents and grandparents) benefits children Assessing and addressing: Loyalty issues Fairness Parentification Checking and restoring age-appropriate balance of 'give and take' It is desireable to restore relationships with parents even who abused their children because it is a way to self-freedom Who was there for you? When you needed someone, who did you turn to? Who did your parent (s) turn to during times of need? Who did your parent (s) confide in most? Whom were you able to rely on in times of need? Whom were your parents able to rely on in times of need? Whom could you trust in your family to see your best interests? Whom could your parents trust in the family/their parents to seek their best interests? Have you ever felt betrayed by any of your family members? Have you heard from your parents or other family members that they felt betrayed or unsupported by the family?
