theoretical-perspectives-on-the-family-(.title: Demographic Transition
theoretical-perspectives-on-the-family-(.description: Based on observed changes across countries throughout the world that are experiencing different paces of industrialization (things like the industrial revolutions, advances in germ theory, access to clean water, hygiene, food availability, and wars) Good summary: This is a state of high birth and death rates culminating in low population growth overall. With a consistently high birth rate and decreasing death rate, population growth surges. As the birth rate falls and the death rate remains low, the population continues to increase. Traditionally considered to be the final stage, this is one of demographic stabilization, in which both birth and death rates are low. This means that the overall population stays fairly low. This final, contested stage may predict higher or lower fertility levels depending on which theorist you ask.

theoretical-perspectives-on-the-family-(.description:
The Institute for Population Research & Census are examples of what demographers do.
May sound familiar as you often need to include “demographics” in your research projects.
Traditionally defined as studying three population processes, fertility, mortality, and migrations. More modern conceptualizations are social demography that seek to study population processes that may not fully align with these big three (e.g., Family Demography is a big field). Family Demography typically two types of studies: Careful tracking and measurement of families at either a given time point or trends over time. Focus on the social, cultural, and economic correlates, precursors, and consequences of family structure and transitions.

theoretical-perspectives-on-the-family-(.title: 2. Family Science and Demography
theoretical-perspectives-on-the-family-(.description:
Read @bellMetatheorizingFamilyTheory2022
Read @smockDemographyFamiliesReview2022
Read @balzariniDyadReviewNovel2020 Every theory we discuss is limited in some way because it presents a particular way of view the world or a particular phenomenon.  Assumptions of the theory help us understand the limitations or boundaries of a particular theory. Examples: Economic and exchange theories Assume that all behavior is reducible to rewards/costs of behavioral exchanges.
Attachment theory (Attachment Theory) Assumes that our template for socializing with people can be primarily explained by the relationship with have with a primary attachment figure.
Family Systems Theory (Family Systems Theory) Assumes all behaviors are linked to the larger social unit of analysis. While each of these are partly true, not every interaction we have in a relationship is rationale (e.g., Exchange theory: sometimes we make costly decisions in a relationship even when we know another behavior my help the relationship are we more motivated for ourselves or the relationship? Attachment theory Although our relationship with primary caregivers are important in childhood, attachment theory doesn’t necessarily deal with genetic, personality, or environmental constraints/affordances that can shape these relationships; Family systems: although family dynamics are powerful, where is the role of autonomy and self-efficacy that can explain shifts away from embedded family norms and patterns of behaviors?) Concepts are the key features of a theory. These are the ideas/concepts (often variables) that we measure and focus on when we think of theory. For example, if you were interested in conducting a study around (social exchange, attachment, or family systems theory) what would you potentially be interested in measuring in your study? – give an example if none come up). Exactly, concepts are the ideas/constructs that allow us to think/apply the theory to something we are interested in studying. These are the hypotheses based on the assumptions and constructs in a given theory. For example, one proposition we might pull from social exchange theory is that in a relationship, when potential alternatives (e.g., other partners) seem more rewarding than our current relationships, we could expect someone might choose to end the relationship or cheat. For attachment theory, we could hypothesize that when someone is high in the anxiety dimension of attachment, they might seem more reassurance from their partner than someone lower in anxiety. For family systems, we could hypothesize that when families have rigid boundaries, it may be harder to intervene and change a child’s problematic behavior than if the family had less rigid boundaries. Ontology = ways of being
Realism There is a real world our theories can describe, and we should have and use theories that describe the real world. How do observations and experiences determine to understand the real world?
Critical Realism The world is knowable, but the focus is on the mechanism that governs people within social structures.
Skepticism We cannot truly know if our theories apply to the real world. How do we consider something understudied?
Epistemology = ways of knowing
Realism Throughout the semester, we will talk about theories that are grand/abstract/critical—they present a big picture way of viewing the world. To mid-range or lower-range theories that attempt to explain and provide specific hypotheses about families or specific family behaviors/outcomes. This idea is helpful to keep in mind as not all theories are well-suited for every level of analysis. Some theories may be better suited for certain methodologies than others. We primarily use contextual theory. Abstract Theory
Implicit Abstract Theory describes connections / links / causes.
Explicit Abstract Theory adds an explanation about the connection / links. Contextual Theory Connects abstract theory to the real world. (This is the world we primarily work in as family scientists). These are more testable theories.
A good comparison might be Socioecological Theory is more of an abstract theory and the ABC-X model is more of a contextual theory. The book discusses an example about family = abstract while stepfamily = contextual.
Descriptive Statements A theoretical concept like family cohesion in a contextual theory might appear in a hypothesis as a set of survey questions about how close people in a family feel to one another, in a narrative description as an informant’s story about family celebrations, or in an empirical generalization as the frequency of family meals. Descriptive statements are more about observable/measurable concepts.
Deduction We can identify and measure concepts that allow us to test a hypothesis. We believe its true if the observations agree, and false if they do not.
Induction Moving from observations to develop theory (a qualitative approach), he argues there is no real logic or repeatable pattern that can always help us move from observations to “true” theory.
Uniformity Principle What will happen in the future will be the same as in the past.
Abduction Theory is a creative process of moving from observation to theory. Use imagination, experience, literature, or intuition to generate theory Use justification to provide logical account connecting observation to theory Interplay between all three—starts with abduction to generate and develop theory, then deduction to develop/test theory – induction helps make sense of testing theory. Standpoint Reality is subjective and a function of our unique experiences/standpoints. We can only know/theorize about things we have experienced. Marginalized groups have a unique perspective.
Postmodern Skepticism There is no one, knowable reality. Abstract theory is too general, stems from theorists' own social positions, and ignores power.
Positivism Attempts to generate general rules that could be used to develop theory to produce unbiased research/hypotheses (we now know there is no such thing). Language of observations = language to turn theory into a descriptive statement
Empiricism Focus on predicting observations based on theory (not on explanation, though)
Falsification Theory could be deductive or inductive by to research to falsify the theory. The theory is only true because it has not been falsified. The more it holds up, the more we can be confident it’s a reliable theory. Multiple frameworks operate simultaneously, but also within each framework, there is a ”normal science” paradigm for each theory within sub-disciplines. Challenge with multiple frameworks is the different meanings available based on different theories. Conflicts between different paradigms/theories are often a function of politics, which my also reflect societal changes in the U.S.
Incommensurability can occur between researchers based on their own positionalities, and we now understand and see that theories were inattentive to other people’s experiences, ways of thinking, and doing science/theorizing. This also helps us understand how certain fields have similar concepts with different names. Give examples—spanking research by Liz Gershoff, minority vs minoritized Using contextual theory, fam scientists have integrated multiple philosophies (e.g., the uncertainty of measurement conceptualized through alphas and p-values to inform falsification/hypothesis testing). Also, family scientists are skeptics that many concepts are made up and can never know if they fully match Reality. Also use operationalization (logical empiricists) to measure concepts while acknowledging that they may imprecisely match theory and observation. “When it comes to theory testing, most family theorists are aware of the limits of falsification, but within those limits are comfortable employing its procedures. “ “Most family scientists believe in verification, sometimes implicitly using Bayesian concepts of probability, so that our confidence in an abstract or contextual theory increases with additional empirical support.” “However, family scientists believe that an accumulation of differently flawed observations can begin to approximate the boundaries of Reality. “ “Family scientists are mostly reasonable realists who anticipate that there is probably a “Real World” out there; we really do believe there are families. However, we also recognize that there are many distinct but overlapping perspectives (frameworks) from which family life can be multiple and simultaneously understood. “ “Family scientists are reasonable skeptics who recognize that many, if not most, of our concepts are made up from our imaginations, and that we will never know how much—or if—they match Reality.” “Mini revolutions, ”e.g., Family scientists integrate multiple theories to make sense of the world Challenge of Meaning “Supernatural explanations for disease, divine spheres for planetary motion, falling objects seeking their proper place, and the “invisible hand” of economics were replaced by germs, gravity, and individual preference schedules do . Why people think they are ill, where a falling object “wants” to be: these sorts of meaning-based explanations are no longer proposed. In these historical cases, meaning explanations have been replaced by causal explanations. “In the end, both realists and skeptics agree that there are limits to what we can know, so whether improved explanations are closer to Truth as realists claim or more useful as practical understanding as skeptics claim, it doesn’t actually make a difference in what we do with our explanations. “ Who defines the concepts? How often do we reevaluate the theoretical frameworks that outline our understanding of families? How might theoretical frameworks help control the ways in which family life is defined and understood within research? Thoughts about theory as described through metaphor? Is our ability to describe theory through metaphor a signal of the utility/practicality of a theory? Will family science have its Newton, who will create a new, grand theoretical framework to replace all the current ones? Coleman (1990) –would it be useful to have a grand theory of family dynamics? What might be some examples of the “challenge of meaning” in HDFS/family science/ your own area? “One thing we learned from Kuhn is that research is accepted when it is persuasive. What is considered persuasive does not distinguish realists from skeptics.” Thoughts about this quote (p 17) The Institute for Population Research & Census are examples of what demographers do. May sound familiar as you often need to include “demographics” in your research projects. Traditionally defined as studying three population processes, fertility, mortality, and migrations. More modern conceptualizations are social demography that seek to study population processes that may not fully align with these big three (e.g., Family Demography is a big field). Family Demography typically two types of studies: Careful tracking and measurement of families at either a given time point or trends over time. Focus on the social, cultural, and economic correlates, precursors, and consequences of family structure and transitions. “Diverging Destinies” framework, articulated by McLanahan (2004), indicates that families are increasingly dissimilar across social class lines, often proxied by educational attainment. A theme you will notice about a lot of demographic and sociological explanations is that they take an economic or structural approach to understanding families, marriage, child-birth, and development.


Most young people still aspire to marriage, yet current trends suggest a retreat from marriage. Declining in married adults partly explained by older age at first marriage (delay in marriage) and fewer people getting married (retreat from marriage). Lower marriage rates for Black Americans (i.e., growing black-white differences in marriage rates). But also true for Hispanic and AINA than White and API women) – Why though? Those with higher SES more likely be married (true for White and Black women). May be explained by economic “readiness” the people link to marriage (it has become a luxury good), which is not as available to those without college degrees. May be explained by marriage market availability and mass incarceration. Second Demographic Transition and the “singles are coming” Remarriage and divorce remain common. Longer time to remarriage for black and Latina women compared to white women. Highest remarriage rates for higher educational levels Post-divorce cohabitation may be replacing marriage given the high divorce rate. Remarriage = more stepfamilies. Divorce rates increased steadily between 1960 and rates remain high since 1970s, but divorce rates have declined since 1980s (though still historically high). May continue to decline as younger adults have lower divorce rates. Paired with older ages of marriage, young adults who marry may also be a select group of more committed people.
Greater divorces rates among older Americans (i.e., 50+) has been called the “Grey Divorce” Largely driven by baby boomers who had high rates of dissolution to begin with. Divorce is dramatically stratified by education with up to 60% of those without HS or GED getting divorced (isn’t it expensive? And might this contribute to income inequality given that divorce and relationship dissolution is typically costly?). Smaller educational difference for Black women compared to White women, but overall the differences between White and Black women, Black women’s marriages were more likely to dissolve. “Since the early 2000s, the relationship between divorce rates and unemployment rates has been negative; that is, when unemployment went down, the divorce rate went up, and when unemployment went up (as during the Great Recession), divorce rates went down” Small effects Recessions delayed rather than forgoing divorce. When men become unemployed when separated, tend to delays divorce. When in economic straights, may be likely to forgo divorce unless remarriage is on the horizon. Marriage may be delayed but people are still not delaying living with intimate partners. Rates of cohabitation with different gender partner sped up since the 1970s. Most women cohabitate by there mid-late twenties. Cohabitation also common among those 50+. Very common to live with a spouse beforehand. Marriage or dissolutions following cohabitation within 2-3 years. Lower likelihood of cohabitation if at least a bachelor’s degree. College-educated women were more likely to transition into marriage from cohabitation than less educated women. Cohabitation is more of a steppingstone to marriage, especially for the more economically disadvantaged Decoupling of marriage and childbearing, as evidenced by increase in cohabitation and retreat from marriage. Increase in non-marital births largely attributed to cohabitating couples. Cohabitation used to be associated with marital instability, but more recent studies do not show this trend. Explanations were selection (cohabitators had more positive attitudes towards divorce). Experiences while cohabiting deterred people from marriage (trial marriage hypothesis). White women who cohabited were more likely to divorce compared to Black and Mexican American women. Cohabitation may stabilize remarriage. Explanation for disappearing cohabitation may be the normative nature of it. Research from other countries supports this idea. Fertility rates of in US have largely declined since 1970s, with a slight increase between 1990s and 2007, after which they continued to fall – this is the case across racial/ethnic groups. Decline since 2007 largely due to declines in birth among young women. Teen births are at an all-time low. US has higher TFR than most European countries, but still below replacement level fertility. Great recession reduced fertility somewhat among younger women, but its unclear if this is a termporary or a longer-term effect. Big decline in fertility for Hispanic immigrants, likely because the recession reduced immigration from Mexico. Not clear why “Longer term structural changes, especially the decline of manufacturing and construction, also depress fertility; thus fertility rates may be unlikely to rebound soon (Seltzer, 2019).” Educational differences in children are relatively small, but more educated women tend to have fewer children. However, recent evidence suggests that fertility rates are increasing among women with advanced degrees. May be explained by these women's ability to outsource childcare, availability of childcare has increased, and spouses participate more in childcare.\ Women college graduates also delay childbirth. 40% of all births are to unmarried women – also, something like 30% - 50% of pregnancies are unintended This tends to be more common for women with less than HS degree (also a group that is less likely to get married and more likely to get divorced.) Non-marital births are increasing for white women, which has contributed to smaller differences in non-marital child birth differences between white/black women. Multi-partner fertility has increased 14%-25% in general — higher in unmarried families and cohabitating families. Less associated with martial fertility in stepfamilies and non-marital fertility. Covid led to a baby “bust.” Same-gender unions Somewhere between 500-800k married same gender couples. Married and cohabitating same-gender couples tend to have higher SES. More schooling Both partners employed Slightly more white Higher median household income Male same-gender couples tend to have higher SES (because of patriarchy). Same-gender couples are less likely to have children (there are many barriers to having children if they aren’t from a previous relationship). Higher rates of childrearing among female same-gender couples. Education gradient in child rearing is more dramatic at higher than lower levels of education for same-gender couples (they have fewer children). “Same-gender couples with children in the home tend to have less education, lower median incomes, and higher poverty rates than different-gender parents despite the fact that same-gender couples as a whole have higher incomes and education than different-gender couples.” When controlling for relevant factors, children in female same-sex couple households have similar poverty rates as those in different gender households. "Controlling for education, demographic, marital status, and health measures, lesbian women and gay men are not more likely to be poor than heterosexuals, but bisexual women and men are more likely to be poor (Badgett, 2018).” We don’t really understand why bisexual people have poorer outcomes. Adoption rates are higher among same-gender unions Still lots of challenges in accessing pathways to parenthood and adoption. Overall decline in parenthood among same-gender couples. Greater dissolution among female same-gender couples. “Since the Great Recession, legal immigration has leveled off, and the size of the undocumented immigrant population has remained relatively constant or declined somewhat, depending on the estimate.” Foreign born population has stayed around 15% between 1890 and 2017 •Most immigrants are from the Americas, particularly, Mexico•“As of 2017, the largest groups of immigrants are from South and East Asia (27%), Mexico (25%), other countries in Latin America (25%), and Europe or Canada (13%; Radford & Noe-Bustamante, 2019).”•Marriage is common 61%, may be due to them being younger/typical age for marriage•24% of Hispanic women will separate or get divorced – this rate has been increasing slowly•There is quite a bit of heterogeneity in divorce rates based on specific ethnic groups (important point to acknowledge when talking about race/ethnicity that’s not covered here.)•“immigration enforcement between 2005 and 2015 raised the likelihood that undocumented mothers lived without their spouses by 20% and the likelihood that Hispanic U.S.-born children lived without their parents by 19%”•Separations are associated with increased poverty, fear, stress, anxiety, and depression•Births to foreign-born women are a large proportion of all births•In 2014, 23% of U.S.-born babies had foreign-born mothers. Most of these births were to women born in Latin America (54%), but the share of births to women born in Latin America has declined since 2010, while the share of births to Asian mothers has increased alongside migration from Asia•These births are compensating for low birth rates from U.S. women and have been important for offsetting population decline in many areas.•Intermarriage rates are disparate across•Marriage and immigration are often linked What might this mean about studying immigrant marriages?•46% of immigrant women married to native-born U.S. citizens married prior to or in the same year as migration.•A lot of changes in childrens living arrangements since the 1970s•12-27% of children lived in single-parent families This stat surprised me•Most single parent households are female-headed•“In 2016, the proportion of all children living in a two-biological parent married household stood at 60%. Roughly 3% lived in a two-parent biological cohabiting family, 9% in a stepparent family, 24% in a single-parent family, and the remainder in other arrangements.”•Stepfamilies are a prominent feature of American families when we consider that many of these families have ties that contain adults rather than children•Many children (about 8% ) live with grand parents.•30% of children have co-resided with a grand parent at some point•Most of these families were multi-generational households (parents and grand parents)•Yet there were also 25% that were skipped generation households (these tend to be more economically vunerable)•“economics and family structure play out in a way that disadvantages children with less-privileged backgrounds and underrepresented minorities.”•“White and Asian families are more likely to be in family structures associated with low poverty rates.”•Family instability has plateaued for education mothers, and generally family complexity had plateaued•“Her work showed that studies on only family instability miss roughly 20% of children’s experiences of instability”•Household instability is negatively associated with childrend educational attainmentQuestions•What were some of your reactions to reading a paper like this that focuses only on documenting rate, trends, and population patterns withing much attention to theory? Was this a first?•Are there any stats that were particularly surprising?•Thoughts about why marriage as most stable family structure?

theoretical-perspectives-on-the-family-(.title: 3. Family Systems Theory and Parent-Child Relationships
theoretical-perspectives-on-the-family-(.description:
CNM people in same-gender relationships COVID social distancing impacts Reinforcing relationship hierarchy Isolate those living alone More time with cohabitating partners -> relationship breakdown Most childcare responsibilities for single parents Less time with parents Non-coparents parenting more Expose Of Polycule to public To COVID (for large networks) Yet, following these best practices has the potential to create or reinforce a relationship hierarchy among cohabiting and non-cohabiting partners or further isolate individuals living alone, according to Sheff (2020 b). In addition, more time among cohabiting partners and disagreements about social distancing practices could lead to tensions and relationship breakdown (Sheff, 2020 a). Single parents or parents working at home in particular may need to take on additional childcare responsibilities (Goldberg et al., 2021), potentially leading to less time with partners or non-coparent partners spending more time with children. Queer Theory Include members who are not biologically or legally connected, and the queer sexuality when they form relationships with more than one person: disentangle romantic, sexual, and coparenting relationships; and include same-gender partners. May openly challenge heteronormative assumptions Not all relationship styles do this May prioritize safety Methods No discussion of the gender composition of the relationships Include members who are not biologically or legally connected, and they queer sexuality when they form relationships with more than one person; disentangle romantic, sexual, and coparenting relationships; and include same-gender partners. However, CNM relationships differ in their degree of compliance with and challenges to heteronormativity. For example, some polyamorous parents try to “pass” as monogamous, whereas others come out and actively compel institutions or other people to recognize their families (Pallotta-Chiarolli, 2010). Decreased contact Connection across distance Distance from children Parents with less time with parents tended to not be cisgender women: only one of these seven parents was a cisgender woman or only a biological parent; rather, three were trans or nonbinary, two were cisgender men, and most were a  combination of stepparents, nonbiological parents, biological parents, and adoptive parents. Pandemic may have more of an impact on parent–child relationships when one or more characteristics of parents deviates from the dominant heteronorm of the primary parent (i.e., female, biological). The children lived with other parents prior to the pandemic, and in others, parents made the decision for children to live with different caregivers such as grandparents or coparents during the pandemic due to risk of exposure (e.g., parent was a frontline worker) or socialization considerations (e.g., the desire to give the child more time with other family members). "A relationship, shared,  a family, we decided it would be good for my kid to spend some time with my ex. Once that happened I have been able to visit my boyfriend twice (after 3 months apart). Both the kid and my ex is happier for the kid being up there.” Hsin-Yi’s account illustrates one way of resolving the desire to see their boyfriend and limit networks of risk exposure while also allowing their child to spend more time with other coparents. Changing dynamics and configurations at home More time at home •This practice of incorporating multiple partners into a living unit could be beneﬁcial in having a “large, robust household” to combat isolation, but also introduced challenges related to sharing space and dividing time among partners. Isabella, a bisexual white polyamorous stepmother to a toddler, elaborated: Fortunately, even those who discussed the stress of living in close quarters commented on the skills and strengths that they possessed as people who engaged in CNM, which enabled them to effectively communicate about their needs and boundaries. But one thing polys are pretty good at is sort of working through issues as they arise.”“Several parents spoke to the strengths of their communication and conflict resolution skills. Another approach to spend more time with partners while avoiding some of the complications of moving everyone into the same house was creating multi-household quarantine pods, which sometimes further challenged heteronormative notions of family through the intentional and collaborative construction of small communities. Increased parenting responsibility Significant stress and desire for greater social support. Support for parents was generally appreciated both by children and co-parents. Negotiating risk For some, this involved a process of pausing and unpausing CNM relationships as participants made decisions about safety and relative risk. Newly exploring CNM, the pandemic seemed to at least temporarily foreclose the possibility of opening the relationship. For other participants with established relationships, the labor and thought that went into seeing existing partners appeared to take priority over the work of trying to safely meet new partners. Others noted their reluctance to meet with new individuals given the politicization of responses to COVID-19. Perhaps because those in CNM relationships often have significant experience communicating needs and boundaries to partners (including negotiating expectations around safer sex behaviors), many participants mentioned the conversations they have with partners about COVID risk without characterizing them as challenging or conflictual. Differences in protective measured ended some relationships.
In what ways are boundaries, as discussed by Family Systems Theory, may be limiting to our understanding of CNM relationships? Is this concept limiting to our understanding of this population? Or is this concept purely expansive in our understanding of this relationship type? During the pandemic, parents had less contact with partners outside of the home and focused more on the children and the biological mother or father of the children. Did the pandemic change the family processes?
Complexity (Effects of the Family Processes via Explanatory Pathways) (Mediation) Conflict affected child behavior problems through parent-to-child hostility in all family configurations except mother-child hostility in unrelated pairs (stepparents?) Genes (relatedness, low serotonin) Anger mediated association between parenting hostility and child health only for those with low serotonin. Inclusion of Siblings Child trauma symptoms is higher when siblings are treated more harshly and more parenting stress; consistent parenting for siblings; older sibling influence of delinquency (bidirectional)
Inclusion of dyadic and triadic processes (e.g., Triangulation) Family-level constructs (e.g., boundary disturbances associated with emotional dysregulation)
Specificity (Identification of moderating factors that suggested for whom or under what conditions associations are salient) ( Moderation) Moderation (e.g., meta-analyses; associations between chronic health condition and sibling well-being - stronger for older siblings and when illness was life-threatening) Advanced the literature by examining moderators that provided important information regarding participant characteristics, sample features, and research methods. The positive association between parents' marital hostility and young adolescents' internalizing problems was significant only when parents' marital cooperation was low (Zhou & Buehler, 2019) Latent class analyses (e.g., association between child effects and harsh parenting strong for those behaving poorly)
Conceptual distinctions (e.g., everyday conflict vs. Acculturation -based conflict) Multiple markers (e.g., adjustment and positive outcomes) Importance of time in the study of family processes and child and adolescent well-being. Future Directions Examination of emotion, cognitive, physiological, and behavioral regulation within and between diverse families Continue research that considers dyadic, triadic, and family-level regulation Focus on studying and enhancing family strengths and reducing risks
Consider both risks and strengths as Predictor s, Mediation (Mediator), and Moderation (Moderator) Continue investigations of gender as a moderator Increased attention to family processes Family Diversity More diverse families (e.g., more inclusive definitions of 'family' - same-sex, between-group comparisons, rural AA families, low-income families) Cultural Adaptations (e.g., FSM)
Revisioning of these theories (Family Systems Theory to include historical time and choice with racial socialization) Importance of time in the study of family processes and child and adolescent well-being Diary Diary Studies (e.g., self-blame associated with you feeling more anger on days with higher conflict) Longitudinal Studies (i.e., growth curves, cross-lagged models) Identifying developmental periods (e.g., violence during toddler and early childhood associated with IPV at age 23) Intergenerational association (e.g., accumulation of family conflict across generations) Changes in family processes (e.g., increased marital conflict associated with children's later disruptive behavior and family conflict in adolescence associated with later youth depressive symptoms) Reciprocal associations (e.g., child anxiety associated with parental hostility but reverse not true when considering other behaviors; reciprocal association between maternal sensitivity and child emotional regulation) Strengths in family functioning Strengths: Reflected in processes that have the potential to be associated with greater child and youth positive development or fewer (or less severe) developmental difficulties or adjustment problems.
Resiliency The capacities of families as functional systems to withstand and rebound from stressful challenges and demands.
Family Cohesion Closeness, support, shared fun Future directions Main takeaways Move beyond markers of child adjustment problems and focus more of positive aspects of well-being (e.g., emotion regulation, healthy sleep, positive affect, positive racial-ethnic identity) Development and reformulation of conceptual models that account for diversity in families The importance of studying everyday lives of families was highlighted and research methods like audio recording and daily diaries were crucial in furthering this area Cross-lagged designs and growth curves were used often There is a lot of variability both within and between families that needs to be studied.

theoretical-perspectives-on-the-family-(.description:
Social Causation Social and economic conditions influence individual functioning and development.
Social Selection Attributes of individuals influence the quality of their social and economic environments.
Interactionist Individual attributes influence a person's social and economic environments.
Hardship conditions are expected to affect family functioning and individual adjustment primarily through the economic pressures they generate. The Family Stress Model proposes that economic pressures include (a) unmet material needs involving necessities such as adequate food and clothing, (b) the inability to pay bills or make ends meet, and (c) having to cut back on even necessary expenses (e.g., health insurance and medical care). When economic pressures is high, parents are at an increased risk for emotional distress (e.g., depression, anxiety, anger, and alienation) and for behavioral problems (e.g., substance use and antisocial behavior). According to the model, these emotional or behavioral problems predict increased marital conflict and reduced marital warmth, and this process diminishes nurturing and involved parenting.

theoretical-perspectives-on-the-family-(.description:
Bibliography: Balzarini, R. N., & Muise, A. (2020). Beyond the Dyad: A Review of the Novel Insights Gained From Studying Consensual Non-monogamy. Current Sexual Health Reports, 12(4), 398–404. https://doi.org/10.1007/s11930-020-00297-x Type: Journal Article Title: Beyond the Dyad: a Review of the Novel Insights Gained From Studying Consensual Non-monogamy, Author: Balzarini, Rhonda N.; Muise, Amy; Journal: Current Sexual Health Reports, Volume: 12, Issue: 4 Pages: 398-404 Year: 2020 DOI: 10.1007/s11930-020-00297-x ISSN: 1548-3584, 1548-3592 Purpose of Review: The purpose of this review is to highlight the major advancements in our understanding of consensually nonmonogamous (CNM) relationships—or intimate relationships between three or more people who are non-exclusive sexually and/ or emotionally. We aim to review key insights from research on the benefits (i.e., diversification of need fulfillment) and challenges (i.e., continued stigma) of CNM relationships and how research on CNM highlights some limitations of the existing theories of relationships. Recent Findings The last two decades have seen a trend towards increasing diversity of family structures. Although monogamy remains the most common relationship structure, CNM relationships are increasing in prevalence and in interest to both lay people and researchers. Recent research has begun to uncover novel insights into who is more likely to be drawn to and engage in CNM, how CNM relationships compare to monogamous relationships, and the potential benefits and challenges of engaging in CNM relationships. Summary While people in CNM relationships still experience stigma, for those who desire such relationships, CNM can be a viable and healthy alternative to monogamy, and may even help people meet more of their needs through diversifying need fulfillment across multiple partners. Despite this, many existing relationship theories are not inclusive of CNM relationship experiences and aspects of existing theories of positive relationships and sexuality may not extend to people in CNM relationships. Moving forward it is important to consider whether our concepts and measures are inclusive to people in diverse relationships, including those in CNM relationships.
Keywords: #Consensual-Non-Monogamy #Need-Fulfillment #Relationship-Quality #Romantic-Relationship #Sexuality #Stigma
“Those who desire such relationships, CNM can be a viable and healthy alternative to monogamy (e.g., it can be just as satisfying as a monogamous relationship; and having multiple simultaneous relationships can help people meet more of their fundamental needs.” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 399)
“Research using nationally representative samples of people from the USA and Canada has shown that approximately 4–6% of individuals report currently being in a CNM relationship.” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 399)
“Far more people have experience with or interest in CNM, with more than 20% of Americans indicating previous participation in some form of CNM in their lifetime.” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 399)
“the prevalence of experience with CNM is even higher among people who identify as bisexual, with approximately 33% reporting previous participation in CNM” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 399)
“CNM is an umbrella term for various nonmonogamous relationship agreements that differ based on the degree to which sexual and emotional needs are consensually fulfilled outside of a romantic dyad” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 399)
“The three types of CNM relationships that are often delineated are swinging, open, and polyamorous relationships” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 399)
“Winging relationships involve temporarily swapping or exchanging partners among couples, often in the context of a specific social event” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 399)
“Open relationships involve extradyadic sex without love and without a romantic partner’s participation” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 399)
“Polyamorous relationships permit loving more than one person, and typically consist of multiple, emotionally close relationships” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 399)
“Although CNM affords emotional and sexual connections with multiple partners simultaneously, polyamory tends to involve close emotional with additional partners than swinging and open relationships, which tend to be primarily about sexual openness” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 399)
“People in CNM relationships often have their own unique agreements with partners and CNM relationship can take on many different structures, but one of the most common configurations, at least for people in polyamorous relationships, is a primary-secondary relationship configuration” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 399)
“In this configuration, a primary relationship is between two partners who typically share household finances, live together, and who are married, and relationships with partners beyond the primary relationship are often referred to as secondary, non-primary, or tertiary partners” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 399)
“less research has examined the configurations of people in open and swinging relationships” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 399)
“because these relationships primarily involve extradyadic sexual encounters, they often follow a similar structure with one partner serving as a primary partner and the other(s) as non-primary” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 399)
“26–43% of people in polyamorous relationships report experiences of stigma and discrimination” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 399)
“monogamous targets were rated more positively than people in CNM relationships in relationship-relevant and relationship-irrelevant domains. That is, monogamous couples were perceived to not only be more trustworthy and passionate but also to be more likely to pay their taxes on time, to floss their teeth, and to walk their dog” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 399)
“some forms of CNM, specifically polyamory, are viewed more favorably than other forms, such as swinging or open relationships” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 399)
“people in CNM relationships continue to face stigma is because these relationships are associated with greater perceived promiscuity and likelihood of having sexually transmitted infections (STIs)” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 399)
“people in monogamous relationships are perceived to be the least promiscuous and to have the lowest STI rates while swingers were perceived as the most,” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 399)
“people in CNM relationships are less likely to contract a sexually transmitted infection than people who identify as monogamous” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 400)
“and CNM individuals are more likely to engage in safer sex practices (e.g., using condoms and getting tested for STIs) than people in monogamous relationships” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 400)
“while people in CNM relationships might engage in sex with multiple partners, all partners are aware of the arrangement and can have an open discussion about their sexual health and extradyadic engagement.” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 400)
“In the USA, 20–25% of people in monogamous relationships engaged in extramarital sex” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 400)
“and people who are in monogamous relationships are less likely to practice safer sex in these encounters than CNM individuals” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 400)
“monogamy might be less effective at preventing STIs than expected” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 400)
“people in CNM relationships are as equally satisfied with and committed to their relationships as individuals in monogamous relationships” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 400)
“individuals in CNM relationships report higher sexual satisfaction and passion” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 400)
“and lower jealousy” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 400)
“han monogamists.” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 400)
“individuals in polyamorous relationships report being more satisfied with, committed to, and invested in their relationships with primary partners compared to secondary partners, but, they report higher sexual frequency” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 400)
“greater sexual satisfaction” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 400)
“and met sexual ideals” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 400)
“with their secondary partner compared to their primary partner.” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 400)
“reports for primary partners and monogamous partners do not differ with regard to commitment or investments, but people in polyamorous relationships tend to report higher sexual frequency, more stigma (e.g., less acceptance from friends and family), and stigma management (e.g., maintaining relationships in secrecy) with secondary partners compared to reports for monogamous partners” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 400)
“One of the potential benefits of engaging in CNM relationships is the diversification of need fulfillment across multiple partners simultaneously” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 400)
“the suffocation model of marriage—which argues that in Western culture, today relative to the past, people expect more from their relationships, and although people who can meet these high expectations can flourish, many people are not investing the time and energy to meet the high expectations they place on their relationships.” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 400)
“people are aiming to meet higher order need for fulfillment and self-actualization without devoting the proper resources” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 400)
“proposed that adopting the tenets of CNM relationships and offloading some needs to additional partners could help strengthen or oxygenate a relationship—serving as one path towards greater need fulfillment.” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 400)
“most cited benefit of CNM reported by 42% of the sample was diversified need fulfillment” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 400)
“one reason people seek out additional partners is to meet needs that are unfulfilled in their current relationships” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 400)
“people who actually opened up to a CNM relationship (compared to those who did not) reported greater sexual satisfaction over the course of two months, and this was especially true if they opened up their relationship to address sexual incompatibilities with their primary partner” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 400)
“relationships with primary partners are characterized by more commitment, investments, and satisfaction and greater communication than relationships with secondary partners” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 400)
“and people tend to rate their primary partners as more desirable long-term partners” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 400)
“relationships with secondary partners are characterized by a greater percentage of time spent on sexual activity” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 401)
“more eroticism” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 401)
“more passion, and greater sexual satisfaction” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 401)
“and yet, secondary partners are considered less desirable long-term mates” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 401)
“three different models to explain the role of need fulfillment in CNM relationships. The proposed models posit that having needs met in one relationship could either (1) detract from the relationship satisfaction in another, concurrent relationship (e.g., contrast model), (2) be associated with greater satisfaction in another, concurrent relationship (e.g., additive model; [57]), or (3) be associated with greater satisfaction in another relationship, but particularly when need fulfillment in the initial relationship is low (e.g., compensation model;” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 401)
“support for the different models has been mixed.” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 401)
“extent to which one partner met aperson’s needs was unrelated to satisfaction or commitment with another partner (inconsistent with the additive or contrast models) and need fulfillment across various needs assessed wasconsistentlyhighwithbothpartner” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 401)
“when a primary partner was more motivated to meet a person’s sexual needs, this was associated with greater sexual satisfaction with their secondary partner (evidence for the additive model), though greater sexual need fulfillment with a secondary partner was associated with less satisfaction with a primary partner (evidence for the contrast model).” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 401)
“when polyamorous individuals reported more eroticism (i.e., feelings of arousal, passion, lust, sexual pleasure) with their primary partners, they reported greater sexual satisfaction with their secondary partner (evidence for the additive model)” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 401)
“though greater eroticism with a secondary partner was associated with less sexual satisfaction with a primary partner (evidence for the contrast model).” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 401)
“ratings of one partner’s nurturance (e.g., feelings of intimacy, warmth, and love) were not associated with sexual satisfaction in other, concurrent relationships suggesting that loving, caring feelings with one partner were not associated with sexual satisfaction with the other partner” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 401)
“mportant future direction will be understanding when, and under what circumstances, relationships with concurrent partners benefit or detract from relationship quality with the other.” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 401)
“when people in CNM relationships had a primary partner who was more communal (e.g., motivated to meet their needs), they were able to be more satisfied in their secondary relationships—suggesting that having a communal primary partner (or other features of the primary) can help people maximize the benefits of multiple concurrent relationships.” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 401)
“CNM participants reported talking about their extra-dyadic sexual experiences and downplaying these sexual experiences more often with their primary partner compared to their secondary partner,” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 401)
“scholars have recently argued that many theories in the psychology of relationships and sexuality include conceptualizations of relationship quality that have an implicit assumption that monogamy is the most desirable relationship style” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 401)
“one of the standard approaches for assessing love in relationships involves asking participants about their passionate and companionate love for their partner” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 401)
“Passionate Love Scale [60] includes the item “I’d get jealous if I thought [my partner] were falling in love with someone else.” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 401)
“participants who are in CNM relationships would score lower on passionate love due to lower levels of reported jealousy despite experiences of passion with partners” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 402)
“attachment theory is arguably among the most widely studied theories of romantic relationships. Attachment theory posits that romantic bonds are important sources of support, emotional stability, and safety and that secure attachment comes from repeated exposure to safe and supportive care” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 402)
“individuals in CNM relationships report high relationship quality, open communication, high levels of honesty, trust, and intimacy, and low levels of jealousy” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 402)
“ll qualities that are analogous to those that characterize a secure attachment” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 402)
“differs is relational exclusivity—or the assumption that pair bonding and love occurs among those who are sexually and romantically exclusive with their partners.” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 402)
“people in CNM relationships have similar attachment orientations with each of their partners (though greater security was reported for their primary partner) and report greater security” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 402)
“beg the question of the built-in assumptions in our theories while providing novel tests of the boundaries of existing theories.” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 402)
“future research could explore more nuanced questions about the benefits and challenges of navigating relationships with multiple partners.” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 402)
“Multi-partner Relationship Maintenance Strategies Scale (MRMSS)” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 402)
“hat will assess how people who pursue multipartner romance (e.g., polyamory, open relationships, swinging, plural marriage) regulate their own and their partners’ sexual and intimate interactions with other people.” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 402)
“research on CNM has either utilized existing scales that have been created with the implicit assumption that monogamy is the most desirable relationship style” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 402)
“or has had to create their own scales to more adequately capture relational processes beyond the dyad” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 402)
“it is important to think about whether our concepts and measures are inclusive to people in diverse relationships, including those in CNM relationships.” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 402)
“how we ask about commitment (do we assume commitment equates with monogamy?) and how we ask about infidelity (do we assume any extradyadic relationships are cheating?)” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 402)
“there are opportunities for future research to expand our understanding of relationship quality and maintenance by re-considering the role of monogamy and by testing whether tenets of CNM relationships have broad implications for understanding need fulfillment.” (Balzarini and Muise, 2020, p. 402)

theoretical-perspectives-on-the-family-(.title: @bellMetatheorizingFamilyTheory2022
theoretical-perspectives-on-the-family-(.description: Bibliography: Bell, D. C. (2022). Metatheorizing in Family Theory. In K. Adamsons, A. L. Few-Demo, C. Proulx, & K. Roy (Eds.), Sourcebook of Family Theories and Methodologies (pp. 21–40). Springer International Publishing. https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-030-92002-9_2 Type: Book Section Title: Metatheorizing in Family Theory, Author: Bell, David C.; Editor: Adamsons, Kari; Few-Demo, April L.; Proulx, Christine; Roy, Kevin; Publisher: Springer International Publishing, Location: Cham, Pages: 21-40 Year: 2022 ISBN: 978-3-030-92001-2 978-3-030-92002-9 A key purpose of theorizing in family science is to develop explanations of family phenomena. There are other purposes for which theory might be constructed (Klein & White, 1996; Schneider, 2006; Swedberg, 2014), but in this chapter, I will discuss theory for the purpose of explanation (Bengtson et  al., 2005a; Fine & Fincham, 2013a). Theories are created by theorizing, and theorizing is thus any process by which a researcher develops explanations. While theorizing is about understanding the world, metatheorizing is about understanding theorizing. One may distinguish three different kinds of metatheorizing (Ritzer, 1988): • Metatheorizing to summarize, interpret, and/or critique (the contents of) prior theory. • Metatheorizing to propose rules for effective theorizing. This includes textbooks on theorizing (D. C. Bell, 2009; Chafetz, 1978; Hage, 1972; Swedberg, 2014). • Metatheorizing to describe and evaluate methods of theorizing, largely conducted by philosophers (e.g., Godfrey-Smith, 2003; Hempel, 1965; Popper, 1965; Staley, 2014). This chapter will emphasize the third type of metatheorizing, a discussion which will naturally touch to some extent on metatheorizing of the second type. Keywords: In Progress

Type: Journal Article
Title: The Demography of Families: A Review of Patterns and Change, Author: Smock, Pamela J; Schwartz, Christine R; Journal: Journal of Marriage and Family, Pages: 9-34
Year: 2022 The authors review demographic trends and research on families in the United States, with a special focus on the past decade. They consider the following several topics: (a) marriage and remarriage, (b) divorce, (c) cohabitation, (d) fertility, (e) same-gender unions, (f) immigrant families, and (g) children’s living arrangements. Throughout, the authors review both overall trends and patterns as well as those by social class and race–ethnicity. The authors discuss major strands of recent research, emphasizing emerging themes and promising directions. They close with a summary of central patterns and trends and conclude that recent trends are not as uniform as they tended to be in earlier decades, making the description of family change increasingly complex.
Keywords: In Progress

Bibliography: Baptist, J., & Hamon, R. R. (2022). Family Systems Theory. In K. Adamsons, A. L. Few-Demo, C. Proulx, & K. Roy (Eds.), Sourcebook of Family Theories and Methodologies (pp. 209–226). Springer International Publishing. https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-030-92002-9_14 Type: Book Section Title: Family Systems Theory, Author: Baptist, Joyce; Hamon, Raeann R.; Editor: Adamsons, Kari; Few-Demo, April L.; Proulx, Christine; Roy, Kevin; Publisher: Springer International Publishing, Location: Cham, Pages: 209-226 Year: 2022 ISBN: 978-3-030-92001-2 978-3-030-92002-9 Family systems theory holds special significance for the field of family science. In fact, a family systems perspective, or seeing the whole as greater than the sum of the individual parts, is “core” to the discipline’s identity and much of what makes family science “a unique and unified discipline.” Consequently, this chapter describes the origins of general systems and family systems theories, outlines the theory’s core assumptions and key concepts, describes three middle-range theories of note, identifies limitations of the theory, and offers suggestions for growth and expansion of systems theory. In order to demonstrate how a theoretical framework can be challenged by collectivist culture, we use empirical exemplars highlighting Asian American family science in an illustration. This endeavor seems timely given that this chapter is written during the COVID-19 pandemic and anti-Asian racism is on the rise in the United States.
Systems theory emerged in the 1920 s when Ludwig von Bertalanffy, an Austrian biologist, proposed a systems approach in the production and implementation of defense systems in order to optimize efficiency, success, and network interactions. In 1954, von Bertalanffy, along with biomathematician Anatol Rapoport, economist Kenneth Boulding, and physiologist Ralph Gerard founded the Society for General Systems Research. In the late 1940s, independent from von Bertalanffy, Norbert Weiner, a philosopher and mathematician, tried to unite mechanists, who saw living organisms functioning like machines, and vitalists who saw little connection between laws governing living and nonliving things. Weiner (1948) contributed the principles of homeostasis and self-regulation through feedback. Before the 1900s, there were no theories dedicated to analyzing families. The concept of the family system was fundamental to Talcott Parsons’ structural functional theory, the most important paradigm in the field of sociology during the 1940s and 1950s. Parson and Bales (1955) identified a four-role family system to include the instrumental leader, the expressive leader, the instrumental follower and the expressive follower. Structural functional theory was more concerned about conformism in defense of the system to the point of neglecting the system’s equally important need for, and capacity to, change.

theoretical-perspectives-on-the-family-(.title: @finkelSuffocationMarriageClimbing2014
theoretical-perspectives-on-the-family-(.description:
Bibliography: Finkel, E. J., Hui, C. M., Carswell, K. L., & Larson, G. M. (2014). The Suffocation of Marriage: Climbing Mount Maslow Without Enough Oxygen. Psychological Inquiry, 25(1), 1–41. https://doi.org/10.1080/1047840X.2014.863723 Type: Journal Article Title: The Suffocation of Marriage: Climbing Mount Maslow Without Enough Oxygen, Author: Finkel, Eli J.; Hui, Chin Ming; Carswell, Kathleen L.; Larson, Grace M.; Journal: Psychological Inquiry, Volume: 25, Issue: 1 Pages: 1-41 Year: 2014 DOI: 10.1080/1047840X.2014.863723 ISSN: 1047-840X, 1532-7965 This article distills insights from historical, sociological, and psychological perspectives on marriage to develop the suffocation model of marriage in America. According to this model, contemporary Americans are asking their marriage to help them fulﬁll different sets of goals than in the past. Whereas they ask their marriage to help them fulﬁll their physiological and safety needs much less than in the past, they ask it to help them fulﬁll their esteem and self-actualization needs much more than in the past. Asking the marriage to help them fulﬁll the latter, higher level needs typically requires sufﬁcient investment of time and psychological resources to ensure that the two spouses develop a deep bond and profound insight into each other’s essential qualities. Although some spouses are investing sufﬁcient resources—and reaping the marital and psychological beneﬁts of doing so—most are not. Indeed, they are, on average, investing less than in the past. As a result, mean levels of marital quality and personal well-being are declining over time. According to the suffocation model, spouses who are struggling with an imbalance between what they are asking from their marriage and what they are investing in it have several promising options for corrective action: intervening to optimize their available resources, increasing their investment of resources in the marriage, and asking less of the marriage in terms of facilitating the fulﬁllment of spouses’ higher needs. Discussion explores the implications of the suffocation model for understanding dating and courtship, sociodemographic variation, and marriage beyond American’s borders. Keywords: Marriage is a means to various ends, a pathway through which people pursue certain goals. Historical changes in American marriage since the late 1700 s, the time of the nation's founding, adopting the perspective that America has witnessed three dominant models of marriage. The first, which extended from the late 1700 s until around 1850, was a practical model in which marriage was primarily oriented toward helping spouses meet their economic, political, and pragmatic goals. The second, from around 1850 until around 1965, was a breadwinner-homemaker model (which included romanticized and companionate subperiods) in which marriage was primarily oriented towards helping spouses meet their passion and intimacy needs. The third, from around 1865 until today, was (and continues to be) a self-expressive model in which marriage was (and is) primarily oriented toward helping spouses meet their autonomy and personal growth needs. The primary functions of marriage have ascended Abraham Maslow's (1943, 1954/1970) hierarchy of needs, which, from bottom to top, encompasses physiological needs, safety needs, belonging and love needs, esteem needs, and self-actualization needs. The Suffocation Model These tenets build upon three properties of Maslow's theory of human motivation. The first property is that needs people seek to fulfill are arranged hierarchically, with lower needs typically possessing greater motivational priority than higher needs. The second is that relative to the successful pursuit of higher needs (to achieve mastery, to experience personal growth, etc.) is more likely to require self-insight, and the development of such self-insight frequently requires considerable cognitive and psychological effort over a sustained period. The third is that the fulfillment of higher needs yields especially high levels of happiness, serenity, and richness of life. One central means through which Americans seek to fulfill their needs is through their marriage, especially as their access to nonspousal significant others has declined. Since the nation's founding, the extent to which Americans look to their marriage to help them fulfill their lower needs has decreased, whereas the extent to which they look to their marriage to help them fulfill their higher needs has increased. Just as the pursuit of higher needs frequently requires substantial insights into the self, looking to the marriage to help individuals fulfill their higher needs frequently requires that each spouse have substantial insight into the partner, and the development of such insight into the partner, and the development of such insight typically requires considerable communication and responsiveness over a sustained period. Even as Americans increasingly look to their marriage to help them fulfill their higher needs, they have, on average, reduced their investment of time and psychological resources in their marriage. In conjunction, the resource imbalance, resulting from the trends described in Tenets 2, 3, and 4 - insufficient investment to meet the emphasis on higher needs - has undermined spouses' marital quality and personal well-being (although those spouses who manage to invest sufficient resources experience especially strong marital quality and personal well-being). Spouses experiencing the adverse effects described in Tenet 5 have three general options for ameliorating or reversing these consequences: Optimizing their usage of the resources that are available Increasing their investment of time and psychological resources in their marriage Asking less of the marriage in terms of facilitating their higher needs. The contemporary American model of marriage is the product of a succession of cultural developments that altered marriage's raisons d'etre over time. These raisons d'etre shifted from: Economics, politics, and pragmatism (late 1700s to 1850) Passion and affection (1850 to 1965) Self-expression and personal growth (1965 to the present) Burgess and Locke (1945) characterized the shift from the first to the second emphasis as a transition from institutional to companionate marriage, and Cherline (2009) characterized the shift from the second to the third emphasis as a transition from companionate to individualistic, or self-expressive, marriage. It is important to recognize that, as with biological evolution, cultural evolution is more of a tinkering process than an engineering process.
Sociologist Ernest Burgess characterized institutional marriages as formal institutions that were strictly regulated by law, social norms, and religion. (Institutional Marriage) According to Burgess, farm families dominated the marital landscape prior to the last few decades of the nineteenth century. In early America, strong and stable marriages were essential to the welfare of family members and the larger community. Family members relied on one another to meet basic needs, including economic production, child care, education, and elder care. Marriage also created bonds between families that facilitated the sharing of resources. Because cohesive, stable, and interconnected families were necessary for survival, society had an interest in regulating marriage and the behavior of individual spouses. In this model, the stability of the family was more important than the needs of the individual family members. Children typically were not allowed to marry without parental permission, and divorce was unacceptable except in the most extreme cases of abuse or abandonment. The raisons d’ˆ etre of marriage were, both directly and indirectly (via broader social processes), related to lower needs in Maslow’s hierarchy. Spouses looked to their marriage to help them fulfill physiological needs such as having enough food to eat, keeping warm in the winter, and having a place to sleep in inclement weather. Spouses also looked to their marriage to help them fulfill safety needs such as being protected from violent attack, having a predictable daily existence, and maintaining a sense of economic security. In many late-1700 s American communities, market economies were strengthening, which began to enable young Americans to work for wages outside their home and to settle at greater distances from their family of origin. At the same time, the influence of Protestant churches, which had historically exerted substantial control over young adults’ marital choices, was declining. These changes dovetailed with an Enlightenment-era worldview that valued the so-called natural passions, including love and romantic desire. Such economic, geographic, and philosophical developments began to reduce the influence of parental approval in marital decisions, which afforded individuals greater freedom in selecting a spouse, trends that rapidly accelerated staring around 1850. Even with the trend toward wage labor outside the home, there was still a need for someone to attend to domestic tasks. For a wife to specialize in domestic production was often efficient, especially given women’s unique biological contributions to childbearing and early childrearing, and having women adopt the homemaking role aligned with prevalent views of women as delicate, virtuous, and sensitive. As wives' labor became less central to household economic success, society shifted to sentimental reasons for marriage. "As the new rules surrounding marriage relaxed, a new idea gained prominence: rather being based on a code of obligations to society and religion, marriage should be based on ties of affection and companionship between spouses. "

theoretical-perspectives-on-the-family-(.description: Bibliography: Conger, R. D., & Donnellan, M. B. (2007). An Interactionist Perspective on the Socioeconomic Context of Human Development. Annual Review of Psychology, 58(1), 175–199. https://doi.org/10.1146/annurev.psych.58.110405.085551 Type: Journal Article Title: An Interactionist Perspective on the Socioeconomic Context of Human Development, Author: Conger, Rand D.; Donnellan, M. Brent; Journal: Annual Review of Psychology, Volume: 58, Issue: 1 Pages: 175-199 Year: 2007 DOI: 10.1146/annurev.psych.58.110405.085551 ISSN: 0066-4308, 1545-2085 This article addresses the relationship between socioeconomic status (SES), family processes, and human development. The topic is framed as part of the general issue of health disparities, which involves the oft-observed positive relationship between SES and the cognitive, social, emotional, and physical well-being of adults and children. A review of recent research and theory identiﬁes three general theoretical approaches that provide possible explanations for the association between SES and individual development: the social causation, social selection, and interactionist perspectives. Empirical evidence demonstrates support for the social causation view that SES affects families and the development of children in terms of both family stress processes (the family stress model) and family investments in children (the family investment model). However, there also is empirical support for the social selection argument that individual characteristics lead to differences in SES. Especially important, recent research is consistent with an interactionist approach, which proposes a dynamic relationship between SES and developmental change over time. Drawing on the combined set of research ﬁndings, the article concludes with the description of an interactionist model that serves as a heuristic for future studies of the links among SES, parenting behaviors, and child development. Keywords: In Progress
